{"uri": "2024-05-371244592", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "19:04:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T19:04:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T18:30:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.news18.com/world/gaza-officials-say-israeli-tanks-shell-evacuation-zone-near-rafah-israel-denies-it-8907892.html", "title": "Gaza Officials Say Israeli Tanks Shell Evacuation Zone Near Rafah, Israel Denies It", "body": "Israel's military denied striking a tent camp west of the city of Rafah on Tuesday after Gaza health authorities said Israeli tank shelling had killed at least 21 people there, in what Israel has designated a civilian evacuation zone.\n\nCAIRO: Israel's military denied striking a tent camp west of the city of Rafah on Tuesday after Gaza health authorities said Israeli tank shelling had killed at least 21 people there, in what Israel has designated a civilian evacuation zone.\n\nEarlier, defying an appeal from the International Court of Justice (ICJ), Israeli tanks advanced to the heart of Rafah for the first time after a night of heavy bombardment, while Spain, Ireland and Norway officially recognised a Palestinian state, a move that further deepened Israel's international isolation.\n\nTwo days after an Israeli airstrike on another camp stirred global condemnation, Gaza emergency services said four tank shells hit a cluster of tents in Al-Mawasi, a coastal strip that Israel had advised civilians in Rafah to move to for safety.\n\nAt least 12 of the dead were women, according to medical officials in the Hamas militant-run Palestinian enclave.\n\nBut Israel's military later said in a statement: \"Contrary to the reports from the last few hours, the IDF (Israel Defence Forces) did not strike in the Humanitarian Area in Al-Mawasi.\"\n\nTuesday's incident in Al-Mawasi occurred in an area designated by Israel as an expanded humanitarian zone. Israel had urged Palestinian civilians in Rafah, including around one million displaced by the almost eight-month-old war, to evacuate there when it launched its incursion in early May.\n\nIn central Rafah, tanks and armoured vehicles mounted with machineguns were spotted near Al-Awda mosque, a city landmark, witnesses told Reuters. The Israeli military said its forces continued to operate in the Rafah area, without commenting on reported advances into the city centre.\n\nOUTRAGE\n\nInternational unease over Israel's three-week-old Rafah offensive has turned to outrage after an attack on Sunday set off a blaze in a tent camp in a western district of the city, killing at least 45 people.\n\nIsrael said it had targeted two senior Hamas operatives and had not intended to cause civilian casualties.\n\nGlobal leaders voiced horror at the fire in a designated \"humanitarian zone\" of Rafah where families uprooted by fighting elsewhere had sought shelter, and urged the implementation of a World Court order last week for a halt to Israel's assault.\n\nThe Israeli military said it was investigating the possibility that munitions stored near a compound targeted by Sunday's airstrike may have ignited and touched off the blaze.\n\nResidents said Rafah's Tel Al-Sultan neighbourhood, the scene of Sunday's night-time strike in which tents and shelters were set ablaze as families settled down to sleep, was still being bombarded.\n\n\"Tank shells are falling everywhere in Tel Al-Sultan. Many families have fled their houses in western Rafah under fire throughout the night,\" one resident told Reuters via a chat app.\n\nU.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres on Tuesday added his voice to the chorus of condemnation of Sunday's strike and again urged Israel to allow \"the immediate, safe and unhindered delivery of humanitarian assistance to those in need\".\n\nIn a further blow to aid efforts, a part of the U.S. military's pier off Gaza's coast has broken off, probably due to bad weather, rendering it temporarily inoperable, two U.S. officials said. The United Nations has transported 137 trucks of aid from the pier since it began operations two weeks ago.\n\nSpain, Norway and Ireland said they hoped their decision to recognise a Palestinian state would speed up efforts towards securing a ceasefire in Israel's war against Hamas militants, which has reduced much of the densely populated territory to rubble.\n\nEgypt is again trying in tandem with Qatar and the U.S. to revive talks on a ceasefire and the release of hostages held by Hamas, but efforts have been hampered by Israel's assault on Rafah, Cairo's state-affiliated Al-Qahera News TV channel said on Tuesday, citing a senior official.\n\nAround one million people - many repeatedly uprooted by shifting waves of the war - have fled the Israeli offensive in Rafah since early May, the U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees (UNRWA) reported on Tuesday.\n\nTANKS\n\nIsrael seized control of the Rafah border crossing with Egypt three weeks ago. Its tanks then entered some eastern districts of the city but had previously not rumbled into the centre in full force.\n\nOn Tuesday, witnesses also reported gunbattles between Israeli troops and Hamas-led fighters in the area of the Zurub hilltop in western Rafah.\n\nWitnesses in central Rafah said the Israeli military appeared to have brought in remote-operated armoured vehicles and there was no immediate sign of personnel in or around them. An Israeli military spokesperson had no immediate comment.\n\nThe Israeli military also said it operated overnight along the Philadelphi Corridor that separates Gaza from Egypt and troops were engaged in close-quarter combat, locating tunnel shafts, weapons and militant infrastructure.\n\nMore than 36,000 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's offensive, Gaza's health ministry says. Israel launched its air and ground war after Hamas-led militants attacked southern Israeli communities on Oct. 7, killing around 1,200 people and seizing more than 250 hostages, according to Israeli tallies.\n\nIsrael says it wants to root out the last major intact formations of Hamas fighters hunkered down in Rafah and rescue hostages it says are being held in the area.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8150336282", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "18:27:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T18:27:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T18:25:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.thedailystar.net/news/world/israels-attack-on-palestine/news/gaza-civil-defence-says-21-dead-new-israeli-strike-gaza-camp-3621421", "title": "Gaza civil defence says 21 dead in new Israeli strike on Gaza camp", "body": "Smoke rises following Israeli strikes during an Israeli military operation in Rafah, as seen from Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, May 28, 2024.\n\nA civil defence official in the Hamas-run Gaza Strip said an Israeli strike on a displacement camp west of Rafah on Tuesday killed at least 21 people, days after a similar strike that sparked global outrage.\n\nMohammad al-Mughayyir said they were killed in an \"occupation strike targeting the tents of displaced people west of Rafah.\" Hamas said an Israeli strike had caused \"dozens of martyrs and wounded\" in the area.\n\nIt came as Israeli tanks penetrated the heart of Rafah, according to Palestinian officials, despite widespread condemnation over an air strike on a crowded camp in the southern Gaza city that killed 45 people two days earlier.\n\nIsraeli tanks were \"stationed on the Al-Awda roundabout in the centre of the city of Rafah\", one witness said.\n\nA Palestinian security source said tanks were in central Rafah, where Israeli troops launched a controversial ground assault earlier this month.\n\n\"People are currently inside their homes because anyone who moves is being shot at by Israeli drones,\" one resident, Abdel Khatib, said.\n\nWith an emergency United Nations Security Council meeting at 1915 GMT due to discuss Sunday's strike on the displaced camp, the situation remains tense in Rafah.\n\nIn a statement issued hours before the meeting, Israel's military said the weapons used in Sunday's strike \"could not\" have caused the deadly blaze in the Rafah camp.\n\n\"Our munition alone could not have ignited a fire of this size,\" said military spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari.\n\nSunday evening's strike, which medics said also wounded hundreds of civilians, drew worldwide condemnation.\n\nThe sight of the charred carnage, blackened corpses and children being rushed to hospitals led UN chief Antonio Guterres to declare that \"there is no safe place in Gaza. This horror must stop.\" Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called the strike a \"tragic accident\" but also vowed to continue the campaign to destroy Hamas over the October 7 attack and bring home all the hostages.\n\nMore air strikes and shelling rained down overnight on besieged Gaza -- including the Tal al-Sultan area where the displacement camp went up in flames near a facility of the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, UNRWA.\n\n\"The situation is very dangerous,\" said resident Faten Jouda, 30. \"We didn't sleep all night. There was random bombing from all directions, including artillery shelling and air bombardment as well as firing from aircraft.\n\n\"We saw everyone fleeing again,\" she told AFP. \"We too will go now and head to Al-Mawasi because we fear for our lives,\" she said of a nearby coastal area Israel has declared a safe \"humanitarian zone\".\n\nUNRWA said one million civilians had fled Rafah since Israel launched its assault on the city in early May despite a chorus of international warnings.\n\n\"This happened with nowhere safe to go & amidst bombardments, lack of food & water, piles of waste & unsuitable living conditions,\" it posted on X.\n\nMore than seven months into the deadliest Gaza war, Israel has faced ever louder global opposition, as well as cases before two international courts based in the Netherlands.\n\nIn a landmark political move on Tuesday, Ireland, Norway and Spain formally recognised the State of Palestine, a step so far taken by more than 140 UN members but few Western governments.\n\nSpanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said the recognition was \"not only a matter of historic justice... it is also an essential requirement if we are all to achieve peace\".\n\n\"It is the only way to move towards the solution that we all recognise as the only possible way to achieve a peaceful future: that of a Palestinian state living side by side with the State of Israel in peace and security.\" Irish Prime Minister Simon Harris said the aim was to keep Middle East peace hopes alive, and urged Israel to \"stop the humanitarian catastrophe\" in Gaza.\n\nIsrael has slammed the recognition as a \"reward\" for the Islamist Hamas movement, and recalled its diplomatic envoys from Madrid, Dublin and Oslo.\n\nForeign Minister Israel Katz went further on Tuesday and launched an attack on Sanchez on X, telling him that \"you are a partner to incitement to genocide of the Jewish people\".\n\nSpanish Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Albares said the three governments would \"issue a coordinated response\" to Israel which he said would be \"calm but firm\".\n\nThe Gaza war was sparked by Hamas's October 7 attack on southern Israel, which resulted in the deaths of more than 1,170 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nMilitants also took 252 hostages, 121 of whom remain in Gaza, including 37 the army says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory offensive has killed at least 36,096 people in Gaza, mostly civilians, according to the territory's health ministry.\n\nSunday night's attack that killed dozens in the displaced persons camp was targeting two senior Hamas members, the Israeli military said.\n\nIt said aircraft \"struck a Hamas compound\" and killed Yassin Rabia and Khaled Nagar, senior officials for the group in the occupied West Bank.\n\nThe strike came hours after Hamas had fired a barrage of rockets towards Tel Aviv, with most being intercepted.\n\nThe civilian death toll in the Gaza camp prompted a wave of condemnation, with Palestinians and many Arab countries calling it a \"massacre\".\n\nUNRWA chief Philippe Lazzarini said Monday that \"the images from last night are testament to how Rafah has turned into hell on Earth\".\n\nEU foreign policy chief Joseph Borrell said he was \"horrified\" and French President Emmanuel Macron said he was \"outraged\".\n\nA US National Security Council spokesperson said Israel \"must take every precaution possible to protect civilians\".", "source": {"uri": "thedailystar.net", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8150492421", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "20:51:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T20:51:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T20:50:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13469155/Israeli-strikes-continue-near-Gaza-s-Rafah.html", "title": "Israeli strikes continue near Gaza\u00b4s Rafah", "body": "Renewed Israeli shelling and strikes have killed at least 37 people, most of them sheltering in tents, outside the southern Gaza city of Rafah, according to witnesses, first responders and hospital officials.\n\nThe strikes overnight and on Tuesday pummelled the same area where strikes had triggered a deadly fire that swept through a camp for displaced Palestinian, they said.\n\nThe tent camp inferno has drawn widespread international outrage, including from some of Israel's closest allies, over the military's expanding offensive into Rafah.\n\nAnd in a sign of Israel's growing isolation on the world stage, Spain, Norway and Ireland formally recognised a Palestinian state on Tuesday.\n\nPalestinians fleeing from the southern Gaza city of Rafah during an Israeli ground and air offensive in the city (Abdel Kareem Hana/AP)\n\nThe Israeli military suggested Sunday's blaze in the tent camp may have been caused by secondary explosions, possibly from Palestinian militants' weapons.\n\nThe results of Israel's initial probe into the fire were issued on Tuesday, with military spokesman Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari saying the cause of the fire was still under investigation but that the munitions used - targeting what the army said was a position with two senior Hamas militants - were too small to be the source.\n\nThe strike or the subsequent fire could also have ignited fuel, cooking gas canisters or other materials in the camp.\n\nThe blaze killed 45 Palestinians, according to Gaza health officials' count.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the fire was the result of a \"tragic mishap\".\n\nIsrael's assault on Rafah, launched on May 6, has caused more than one million people to flee the city, the UN agency helping Palestinian refugees said on Tuesday.\n\nMost had already been displaced multiple times in the nearly eight-month war between Israel and Hamas.\n\nIt was a night of horror Abdel-Rahman Abu Ismail, Palestinian from Gaza City\n\nFamilies are now scattered across makeshift tent camps and other war-ravaged areas.\n\nThe strikes over the past few days have hit areas west of Rafah, which had not been ordered by the military to evacuate.\n\nIsraeli ground troops and tanks have been operating in eastern Rafah, in central parts of the city, and along the Gaza-Egypt border.\n\nShelling late on Monday and early on Tuesday hit Rafah's western Tel al-Sultan district, killing at least 16 people, the Palestinian Civil Defence and the Palestinian Red Crescent said.\n\nSeven of the dead were in tents next to a UN facility about 200 metres from the site of Sunday night's strike and fire.\n\n\"It was a night of horror,\" said Abdel-Rahman Abu Ismail, a Palestinian from Gaza City who has been sheltering in Tel al-Sultan since December.\n\nHe said he heard \"constant sounds\" of explosions overnight and into Tuesday, with fighter jets and drones flying over the area.\n\nHe said it reminded him of the Israeli invasion of his neighbourhood of Shijaiyah in Gaza City, where Israel launched a heavy bombing campaign before sending in ground forces in late 2023.\n\nPalestinians fleeing from the southern Gaza city of Rafah during an Israeli ground and air offensive in the city (Jehad Alshrafi/AP)\n\n\"We saw this before,\" he said.\n\nThe United States and other allies of Israel have warned against a full-fledged offensive in the city, with the Biden administration saying that would cross a red line and refusing to provide offensive arms for such an undertaking.\n\nOn Friday, the International Court of Justice called on Israel to halt its Rafah offensive, an order it has no power to enforce.\n\nOn Tuesday afternoon, an Israeli drone strike hit tents near a field hospital by the Mediterranean coast west of Rafah, killing at least 21 people, including 13 women, the Gaza Health Ministry said.\n\nA witness, Ahmed Nassar, said his four cousins and some of their husbands and children were killed in the strike and that a number of tents were destroyed or damaged.\n\nMost of those living there had fled from the same neighbourhood in Gaza City earlier in the war.\n\n\"They have nothing to do with anything,\" he said.\n\nMr Netanyahu has vowed to press ahead, saying Israeli forces must enter Rafah to dismantle Hamas and return hostages taken in the October 7 attack that triggered the war.\n\nPalestinians look at the destruction after an Israeli strike where displaced people were staying in Rafah, Gaza Strip (Jehad Alshrafi/AP)\n\nIn its investigation of Sunday's deadly strike and fire, the Israeli military released satellite photos of what it said was a Hamas rocket launch position about 40 metres from an area of sheds that was targeted.\n\nIn the photo, the alleged launcher itself did not appear to have been struck.\n\nRear Admiral Hagari said Israeli warplanes used the smallest munition possible - two munitions with 17-kilogram warheads.\n\n\"Our munition alone could not have ignited a fire of this size,\" he said.\n\nRear Admiral Hagari said that the fire was \"a devastating incident which we did not expect\" and said it ignited due to \"unforeseen circumstances\".\n\nStill, the strikes have triggered a flight of people from areas west of Rafah.\n\nSayed al-Masri, a Rafah resident, said many families were heading to the crowded Muwasi area or to Khan Younis, a southern city that suffered heavy damage during months of fighting.\n\n\"The situation is worsening\" in Rafah, al-Masri said.\n\nIsraeli soldiers move on the top of a tank near the Israeli-Gaza border, as seen from southern Israel (Leo Correa/AP)\n\nGaza's Health Ministry said two medical facilities in Tel al-Sultan are out of service because of intense bombing nearby.\n\nMedical Aid for Palestinians, a charity operating throughout the territory, said the Tel al-Sultan medical centre and the Indonesian Field Hospital were under lockdown, with medics, patients and displaced people trapped inside.\n\nMost of Gaza's hospitals are no longer functioning.\n\nRafah's Kuwait Hospital shut down on Monday after a strike near its entrance killed two health workers.\n\nA spokesperson for the World Health Organisation said the casualties from Sunday's strike and fire \"absolutely overwhelmed\" field hospitals in the area, which were already running short on supplies to treat severe burns.\n\n\"That requires intensive care, that requires electricity, that requires high-level medical services,\" Dr Margaret Harris told reporters in Geneva.\n\n\"Increasingly, we are struggling to even have the high-level skilled doctors and nurses because they've been displaced.\"\n\n(PA Graphics)\n\nThe war began when Hamas and other militants burst into southern Israel in a surprise attack on October 7, killing some 1,200 civilians and abducting around 250.\n\nMore than 100 were released during a week-long ceasefire in November in exchange for Palestinians imprisoned by Israel.\n\nIsrael responded to the attack with a massive air, land and sea offensive that has killed at least 36,096 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its count.\n\nAround 80% of Gaza's population of 2.3 million has been displaced and United Nations officials say parts of the territory are experiencing famine.\n\nThe fighting in Rafah has made it nearly impossible for humanitarian groups to import and distribute aid to southern Gaza.\n\nThe Israeli military says it has allowed hundreds of trucks to enter through the nearby Kerem Shalom crossing since the start of its operation, but aid groups say it is extremely difficult to access that aid on the Gaza side because of the fighting.\n\nThe UN says it has only been able to collect aid from around 170 trucks over the past three weeks via Kerem Shalom.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8150482116", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "20:40:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T20:40:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T20:40:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/05/28/we-have-nothing-as-israel-attacks-rafah-palestinians-are-living-in-tents-and-searching-for-food/", "title": "Israel's attacks leave Palestinians living in tents, searching for food", "body": "Displaced Palestinians inspect their tents destroyed by Israel's bombardment, adjunct to an UNRWA facility west of Rafah city, Gaza Strip, Tuesday, May 28, 2024. AP Photo/Jehad Alshrafi\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip -- Israeli shelling and airstrikes killed at least 37 people, most of them sheltering in tents, outside the southern Gaza city of Rafah overnight and on Tuesday - pummeling the same area where strikes triggered a deadly fire days earlier in a camp for displaced Palestinians - according to witnesses, emergency workers and hospital officials.\n\nThe tent camp inferno has drawn widespread international outrage, including from some of Israel's closest allies, over the military's expanding offensive into Rafah. And in a sign of Israel's growing isolation on the world stage, Spain, Norway and Ireland formally recognized a Palestinian state on Tuesday.\n\nThe Israeli military suggested Sunday's blaze in the tent camp may have been caused by secondary explosions, possibly from Palestinian militants' weapons. The results of Israel's initial probe into the fire were issued Tuesday, with military spokesman Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari saying the cause of the fire was still under investigation but that the Israeli munitions used - targeting what the army said was a position with two senior Hamas militants - were too small to be the source.\n\nRelated World leaders 'outraged' by deadly Israeli strike on Rafah tent camp\n\nThe strike or the subsequent fire could also have ignited fuel, cooking gas canisters or other materials in the camp. The blaze killed 45 Palestinians, according to Gaza health officials' count. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the fire was the result of a \"tragic mishap.\"\n\nIsrael's assault on Rafah, launched May 6, spurred more than 1 million people to flee the city, the U.N. agency helping Palestinian refugees said Tuesday. Most were already displaced multiple times in the nearly eight-month war between Israel and Hamas. Families are now scattered across makeshift tent camps and other war-ravaged areas.\n\nThe strikes over the past few days have hit areas west of Rafah, where the military had not ordered civilians to evacuate. Israeli ground troops and tanks have been operating in eastern Rafah, in central parts of the city, and along the Gaza-Egypt border.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nDisplaced Palestinians inspect their tents destroyed by Israel's bombardment, adjunct to an UNRWA facility west of Rafah city, Gaza Strip, Tuesday, May 28, 2024. AP Photo/Jehad Alshrafi\n\nShelling late Monday and early Tuesday hit Rafah's western Tel al-Sultan district, killing at least 16 people, the Palestinian Civil Defense and the Palestinian Red Crescent said. Seven of the dead were in tents next to a U.N. facility about about 200 yards from the site of Sunday's fire.\n\n\"It was a night of horror,\" said Abdel-Rahman Abu Ismail, a Palestinian from Gaza City who has been sheltering in Tel al-Sultan since December. He said he heard \"constant sounds\" of explosions overnight and into Tuesday, with fighter jets and drones flying above.\n\nRelated Far-right Israeli settlers step up attacks on aid trucks bound for Gaza\n\nHe said it reminded him of the Israeli invasion of his neighborhood of Shijaiyah in Gaza City, where Israel launched a heavy bombing campaign before sending in ground forces in late 2023. \"We saw this before,\" he said.\n\nThe United States and other allies of Israel have warned against a full-fledged offensive in the city, with the Biden administration saying this would cross a \"red line\" and refusing to provide offensive arms for such an undertaking. On Tuesday, U.S. State Department spokesman Matthew Miller gave no indication the administration sees Israel as crossing any of the red lines for Rafah, saying the offensive is still on a \"far different\" scale than assaults on other population centers in Gaza.\n\nThe International Court of Justice has ordered Israel to halt its Rafah offensive as part of South Africa's case accusing Israel of committing genocide against the Palestinians in Gaza.\n\nOn Tuesday afternoon, an Israeli drone strike hit tents near a field hospital by the Mediterranean coast west of Rafah, killing at least 21 people, including 13 women, Gaza's Health Ministry said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nA witness, Ahmed Nassar, said his four cousins and some of their husbands and children were killed in the strike and a number of tents were destroyed or damaged. Most of those living there had fled from the same neighborhood in Gaza City earlier in the war.\n\n\"They have nothing to do with anything,\" he said.\n\nNetanyahu has vowed to press ahead in Rafah, saying Israeli forces must enter the city to dismantle Hamas and return hostages taken in the Oct. 7 attack that triggered the war.\n\nIn its investigation of Sunday's deadly strike and fire, the Israeli military released satellite photos of what it said was a Hamas rocket launch position about 40 yards from an area of sheds that was targeted. In the photo, the alleged launcher itself did not appear to have been struck.\n\nA tent camp housing Palestinians displaced by the Israeli offensive is seen in Rafah, Gaza Strip, on Feb. 27, 2024. The tent camps stretch for more than 10 miles along Gaza's coast, filling the beach and sprawling into empty lots, fields and town streets. AP Photo/Hatem Ali, file\n\nHe said Israeli warplanes used the smallest bombs possible - two munitions with 40-pound warheads. \"Our munition alone could not have ignited a fire of this size,\" he said.\n\nHagari said that the fire was \"a devastating incident which we did not expect\" and ignited due to \"unforeseen circumstances.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nStill, the strikes have triggered a flight of people from areas west of Rafah. Sayed al-Masri, a Rafah resident, said many families were heading to the crowded Muwasi area or to Khan Younis, a southern city that suffered heavy damage during months of fighting.\n\n\"The situation is worsening\" in Rafah, al-Masri said.\n\nGaza's Health Ministry said two medical facilities in Tel al-Sultan are out of service because of intense bombing nearby. Medical Aid for Palestinians, a charity operating throughout the territory, said the Tel al-Sultan medical center and the Indonesian Field Hospital were under lockdown with medics, patients and displaced people trapped inside.\n\nMost of Gaza's hospitals are no longer functioning. Rafah's Kuwait Hospital shut down Monday after a strike near its entrance killed two health workers.\n\nA spokesperson for the World Health Organization said the casualties from Sunday's strike and fire \"absolutely overwhelmed\" field hospitals in the area, which were already running short on supplies to treat severe burns.\n\n\"That requires intensive care, that requires electricity, that requires high-level medical services,\" Dr. Margaret Harris told reporters in Geneva. \"Increasingly, we are struggling to even have the high-level skilled doctors and nurses because they've been displaced.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe war began when Hamas and other militants burst into southern Israel in a surprise attack on Oct. 7, killing some 1,200 civilians and abducting around 250. More than 100 were released during a weeklong cease-fire in November in exchange for Palestinians imprisoned by Israel.\n\nIsrael responded to the attack with a massive air, land and sea offensive that has killed at least 36,096 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its count. Around 80% of Gaza's population of 2.3 million has been displaced and U.N. officials say parts of the territory are experiencing famine.\n\nThe fighting in Rafah has made it nearly impossible for humanitarian groups to import and distribute aid to southern Gaza.\n\nThe Israeli military says it has allowed hundreds of trucks to enter through the nearby Kerem Shalom crossing since the start of its operation, but aid groups say it's extremely difficult to access that aid on the Gaza side because of the fighting.\n\nThe U.N. says it has only been able to collect aid from around 170 trucks over the past three weeks via Kerem Shalom. Smaller amounts of aid are entering through two crossings in the north and by sea through a U.S.-built floating pier, but it's nowhere near the 600 trucks a day that aid groups say are needed.\n\nCopy {"uri": "2024-05-371269360", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "19:38:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T19:38:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T15:40:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://arab.news/5t9em", "title": "Israeli tanks hit evacuation zone west of Rafah, 21 dead, Gaza health", "body": "The attack site is a coastal area that Israel had advised civilians in Rafah to move to for safety\n\nCAIRO: Israeli strikes on a tent camp in an evacuation area west of Rafah killed at least 21 on Tuesday, Gaza health authorities said, and tanks advanced to the center of the southern Gaza city for the first time after a night of heavy bombardment.\n\nTwo days after an Israeli airstrike on another camp stirred global condemnation, Gaza emergency services said four tank shells hit a cluster of tents in Al-Mawasi, a coastal area that Israel had advised civilians in Rafah to move to for safety.\n\nAt least 12 of the dead were women, according to medical officials in the Hamas-run Palestinian enclave. An Israeli military spokesperson said: \"As of this time, we are not aware of this incident.\"\n\nIn central Rafah, tanks and armored vehicles mounted with machine guns were spotted near Al-Awda mosque, witnesses told Reuters. The Israeli military said its forces continued to operate in the Rafah area, without commenting on reported advances into the city center.\n\nInternational unease over Israel's three-week-old Rafah offensive has turned to outrage after an attack on Sunday set off a blaze in a tent camp in a western district of the city, killing at least 45 people. Israel said it had targeted Hamas commanders and had not intended to cause civilian casualties.\n\nGlobal leaders voiced horror at the fire in a designated \"humanitarian zone\" of Rafah where families uprooted by fighting elsewhere had sought shelter, and urged the implementation of a World Court order last week for a halt to Israel's assault.\n\nTuesday's attack occurred in an area designated by Israel as an expanded humanitarian zone, to which it had called on civilians in Rafah to evacuate for their own safety when it launched its incursion in early May.\n\nIn a diplomatic move purportedly aimed at reining in the violence, Spain, Ireland and Norway were to officially recognize a Palestinian state on Tuesday.\n\nThe three countries have said they hope their decision will accelerate efforts toward securing a ceasefire in Israel's war against Hamas militants, now in its eighth month, that has reduced much of the densely populated territory to rubble.\n\nResidents said Rafah's Tel Al-Sultan neighborhood, the scene of Sunday's night-time strike in which tents and shelters were set ablaze as families settled down to sleep, was still being bombarded.\n\n\"Tank shells are falling everywhere in Tel Al-Sultan. Many families have fled their houses in western Rafah under fire throughout the night,\" one resident told Reuters via a chat app.\n\nAround one million people -- many repeatedly displaced by shifting waves of the war -- have fled the Israeli offensive in Rafah since early May, the UN agency for Palestinian refugees (UNRWA) reported on Tuesday.\n\nA video obtained by Reuters showed families on the move again, carrying their belongings through Rafah's shattered streets, their weary children trailing behind them.\n\n\"There are a lot of attacks, smoke and dust. It is death from God...The (Israelis) are hitting everywhere. We're tired,\" said Moayad Fusaifas, pushing along belongings on two bicycles.\n\nIsrael says it's in combat near Egypt border\n\nSince Israel launched its incursion by seizing control of the Rafah border crossing with Egypt three weeks ago, tanks had probed around the outskirts and entered some eastern districts but had not yet rumbled into the city in full force.\n\nIn recent days, Israeli tanks have thrust toward western neighborhoods and taken up positions on the Zurub hilltop in western Rafah. On Tuesday, witnesses reported gunbattles between Israeli troops and Hamas-led fighters in the Zurub area.\n\nWitnesses in central Rafah said the Israeli military appeared to have brought in remote-operated armored vehicles and there was no immediate sign of personnel in or around them. An Israeli military spokesperson had no immediate comment.\n\nThe Israeli military said it operated overnight along the Philadelphi Corridor that separates Gaza from Egypt \"based on intelligence indicating the presence of terror targets.\"\n\nIsraeli troops were engaged in close-quarter combat and were locating tunnel shafts, weapons and militant infrastructure, it said in a statement.\n\nIsrael has kept up attacks despite the ruling by the International Court of Justice on Friday ordering it to stop given a high risk of civilian casualties. Israel has argued that the top UN court's decision had left it some scope for military action there.\n\nThe ICJ also reiterated calls for the immediate and unconditional release of hostages held in Gaza by Hamas.\n\nMore than 36,000 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's offensive, Gaza's health ministry says. Israel launched its air and ground war after Hamas-led militants attacked southern Israeli communities on Oct. 7, killing around 1,200 people and seizing more than 250 hostages, according to Israeli tallies.\n\nIsrael says it wants to root out Hamas fighters holed up in Rafah and rescue hostages it says are being held in the area.\n\nIn Jabalia in the northern Gaza Strip, one of the largest of the enclave's eight historic refugee camps, Israeli forces have been engaged in fierce fighting with Hamas and Islamic Jihad fighters, residents said.\n\nIn some residential districts from which {"uri": "8150440366", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "20:00:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T20:00:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T19:59:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.staradvertiser.com/2024/05/28/breaking-news/gaza-israeli-tanks-shell-evacuation-zone-near-rafah/", "title": "Gaza: Israeli tanks shell evacuation zone near Rafah | Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "body": "A tank maneuvers near the Israel-Gaza border, amid the ongoing conflict between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas, in Israel, on Monday.\n\nCAIRO >> Israel's military denied striking a tent camp west of the city of Rafah today after Gaza health authorities said Israeli tank shelling had killed at least 21 people there, in what Israel has designated a civilian evacuation zone.\n\nEarlier, defying an appeal from the International Court of Justice (ICJ), Israeli tanks advanced to the heart of Rafah for the first time after a night of heavy bombardment, while Spain, Ireland and Norway officially recognized a Palestinian state, a move that further deepened Israel's international isolation.\n\nTwo days after an Israeli airstrike on another camp stirred global condemnation, Gaza emergency services said four tank shells hit a cluster of tents in Al-Mawasi, a coastal strip that Israel had advised civilians in Rafah to move to for safety.\n\nAt least 12 of the dead were women, according to medical officials in the Hamas militant-run Palestinian enclave.\n\nBut Israel's military later said in a statement: \"Contrary to the reports from the last few hours, the IDF (Israel Defence Forces) did not strike in the Humanitarian Area in Al-Mawasi.\"\n\nToday's incident in Al-Mawasi occurred in an area designated by Israel as an expanded humanitarian zone. Israel had urged Palestinian civilians in Rafah, including around one million displaced by the almost eight-month-old war, to evacuate there when it launched its incursion in early May.\n\nIn central Rafah, tanks and armored vehicles mounted with machineguns were spotted near Al-Awda mosque, a city landmark, witnesses told Reuters. The Israeli military said its forces continued to operate in the Rafah area, without commenting on reported advances into the city center.\n\nOUTRAGE\n\nInternational unease over Israel's three-week-old Rafah offensive has turned to outrage after an attack on Sunday set off a blaze in a tent camp in a western district of the city, killing at least 45 people.\n\nIsrael said it had targeted two senior Hamas operatives and had not intended to cause civilian casualties.\n\nGlobal leaders voiced horror at the fire in a designated \"humanitarian zone\" of Rafah where families uprooted by fighting elsewhere had sought shelter, and urged the implementation of a World Court order last week for a halt to Israel's assault.\n\nThe Israeli military said it was investigating the possibility that munitions stored near a compound targeted by Sunday's airstrike may have ignited and touched off the blaze.\n\nResidents said Rafah's Tel Al-Sultan neighborhood, the scene of Sunday's night-time strike in which tents and shelters were set ablaze as families settled down to sleep, was still being bombarded.\n\n\"Tank shells are falling everywhere in Tel Al-Sultan. Many families have fled their houses in western Rafah under fire throughout the night,\" one resident told Reuters via a chat app.\n\nU.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres today added his voice to the chorus of condemnation of Sunday's strike and again urged Israel to allow \"the immediate, safe and unhindered delivery of humanitarian assistance to those in need\".\n\nIn a further blow to aid efforts, a part of the U.S. military's pier off Gaza's coast has broken off, probably due to bad weather, rendering it temporarily inoperable, two U.S. officials said. The United Nations has transported 137 trucks of aid from the pier since it began operations two weeks ago.\n\nSpain, Norway and Ireland said they hoped their decision to recognize a Palestinian state would speed up efforts towards securing a ceasefire in Israel's war against Hamas militants, which has reduced much of the densely populated territory to rubble.\n\nEgypt is again trying in tandem with Qatar and the U.S. to revive talks on a ceasefire and the release of hostages held by Hamas, but efforts have been hampered by Israel's assault on Rafah, Cairo's state-affiliated Al-Qahera News TV channel said today, citing a senior official.\n\nAround one million people - many repeatedly uprooted by shifting waves of the war - have fled the Israeli offensive in Rafah since early May, the U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees (UNRWA) reported today.\n\nTANKS\n\nIsrael seized control of the Rafah border crossing with Egypt three weeks ago. Its tanks then entered some eastern districts of the city but had previously not rumbled into the center in full force.\n\nWitnesses today also reported gunbattles between Israeli troops and Hamas-led fighters in the area of the Zurub hilltop in western Rafah.\n\nWitnesses in central Rafah said the Israeli military appeared to have brought in remote-operated armored vehicles and there was no immediate sign of personnel in or around them. An Israeli military spokesperson had no immediate comment.\n\nThe Israeli military also said it operated overnight along the Philadelphi Corridor that separates Gaza from Egypt and troops were engaged in close-quarter combat, locating tunnel shafts, weapons and militant infrastructure.\n\nMore than 36,000 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's offensive, Gaza's health ministry says. Israel launched its air and ground war after Hamas-led militants attacked southern Israeli communities on Oct. 7, killing around 1,200 people and seizing more than 250 hostages, according to Israeli tallies.\n\nIsrael says it wants to root out the last major intact formations of Hamas fighters hunkered down in Rafah and rescue hostages it says are being held in the area.", "source": {"uri": "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/21-killed-in-fresh-israeli-strike-on-displacement-camp-in-west-rafah-5766017", "title": "21 Killed In Fresh Israeli Strike On Displacement Camp In West Rafah", "body": "More air strikes and shelling rained down overnight on besieged Gaza (Representational)\n\nRafah:\n\nA civil defence official in the Hamas-run Gaza Strip said an Israeli strike on a displacement camp west of Rafah on Tuesday killed at least 21 people, days after a similar strike that sparked global outrage.\n\nMohammad al-Mughayyir said they were killed in an \"occupation strike targeting the tents of displaced people west of Rafah.\" Hamas said an Israeli strike had caused \"dozens of martyrs and wounded\" in the area.\n\nIt came as Israeli tanks penetrated the heart of Rafah, according to Palestinian officials, despite widespread condemnation over an air strike on a crowded camp in the southern Gaza city that killed 45 people two days earlier.\n\nIsraeli tanks were \"stationed on the Al-Awda roundabout in the centre of the city of Rafah\", one witness said.\n\nA Palestinian security source said tanks were in central Rafah, where Israeli troops launched a controversial ground assault earlier this month.\n\n\"People are currently inside their homes because anyone who moves is being shot at by Israeli drones,\" one resident, Abdel Khatib, said.\n\nWith an emergency United Nations Security Council meeting at 1915 GMT due to discuss Sunday's strike on the displaced camp, the situation remains tense in Rafah.\n\nIn a statement issued hours before the meeting, Israel's military said the weapons used in Sunday's strike \"could not\" have caused the deadly blaze in the Rafah camp.\n\n\"Our munition alone could not have ignited a fire of this size,\" said military spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari.\n\nSunday evening's strike, which medics said also wounded hundreds of civilians, drew worldwide condemnation.\n\nThe sight of the charred carnage, blackened corpses and children being rushed to hospitals led UN chief Antonio Guterres to declare that \"there is no safe place in Gaza. This horror must stop.\"\n\nIsrael's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called the strike a \"tragic accident\" but also vowed to continue the campaign to destroy Hamas over the October 7 attack and bring home all the hostages.\n\nMore air strikes and shelling rained down overnight on besieged Gaza -- including the Tal al-Sultan area where the displacement camp went up in flames near a facility of the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, UNRWA.\n\n\"The situation is very dangerous,\" said resident Faten Jouda, 30. \"We didn't sleep all night. There was random bombing from all directions, including artillery shelling and air bombardment as well as firing from aircraft.\n\n\"We saw everyone fleeing again,\" she told AFP. \"We too will go now and head to Al-Mawasi because we fear for our lives,\" she said of a nearby coastal area Israel has declared a safe \"humanitarian zone\".\n\nUNRWA said one million civilians had fled Rafah since Israel launched its assault on the city in early May despite a chorus of international warnings.\n\n\"This happened with nowhere safe to go & amidst bombardments, lack of food & water, piles of waste & unsuitable living conditions,\" it posted on X.\n\nPalestinian statehood\n\nMore than seven months into the deadliest Gaza war, Israel has faced ever louder global opposition, as well as cases before two international courts based in the Netherlands.\n\nIn a landmark political move on Tuesday, Ireland, Norway and Spain formally recognised the State of Palestine, a step so far taken by more than 140 UN members but few Western governments.\n\nSpanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said the recognition was \"not only a matter of historic justice... it is also an essential requirement if we are all to achieve peace\".\n\n\"It is the only way to move towards the solution that we all recognise as the only possible way to achieve a peaceful future: that of a Palestinian state living side by side with the State of Israel in peace and security.\"\n\nIrish Prime Minister Simon Harris said the aim was to keep Middle East peace hopes alive, and urged Israel to \"stop the humanitarian catastrophe\" in Gaza.\n\nIsrael has slammed the recognition as a \"reward\" for the Islamist Hamas movement, and recalled its diplomatic envoys from Madrid, Dublin and Oslo.\n\nForeign Minister Israel Katz went further on Tuesday and launched an attack on Sanchez on X, telling him that \"you are a partner to incitement to genocide of the Jewish people\".\n\nSpanish Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Albares said the three governments would \"issue a coordinated response\" to Israel which he said would be \"calm but firm\".\n\n'Hell on Earth'\n\nThe Gaza war was sparked by Hamas's October 7 attack on southern Israel, which resulted in the deaths of more than 1,170 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nHamas also took 252 hostages, 121 of whom remain in Gaza, including 37 the army says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory offensive has killed at least 36,096 people in Gaza, mostly civilians, according to the territory's health ministry.\n\nSunday night's attack that killed dozens in the displaced persons camp was targeting two senior Hamas members, the Israeli military said.\n\nIt said aircraft \"struck a Hamas compound\" and killed Yassin Rabia and Khaled Nagar, senior officials for the group in the occupied West Bank.\n\nThe strike came hours after Hamas had fired a barrage of rockets towards Tel Aviv, with most being intercepted.\n\nThe civilian death count in the Gaza camp prompted a wave of condemnation, with Palestinians and many Arab countries calling it a \"massacre\".\n\nUNRWA chief Philippe Lazzarini said Monday that \"the images from last night are testament to how Rafah has turned into hell on Earth\".\n\nEU foreign policy chief Joseph Borrell said he was \"horrified\" and French President Emmanuel Macron said he was \"outraged\".\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\nA US National Security Council spokesperson said Israel \"must take every precaution possible to protect civilians\".\n\n(Except for the headline, this story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is published from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "ndtv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8150462293", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "20:21:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T20:21:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T20:20:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/israeli-strikes-kill-at-least-37-palestinians-most-in-tents-near-gazas-rafah-as-offensive-expands/NTVBTMYXLJHWLKWMVWWOIIO6DA/", "title": "'Night of horror': Palestinians sheltering in tents killed by air strikes", "body": "Israeli shelling and airstrikes killed at least 37 people, most of them sheltering in tents, outside the southern Gaza city of Rafah overnight and on Tuesday - pummeling the same area where strikes triggered a deadly fire days earlier in a camp for displaced Palestinians - according to witnesses, emergency workers and hospital officials.\n\nThe tent camp inferno has drawn widespread international outrage, including from some of Israel's closest allies, over the military's expanding offensive into Rafah. And in a sign of Israel's growing isolation on the world stage, Spain, Norway and Ireland formally recognised a Palestinian state on Tuesday.\n\nThe Israeli military suggested Sunday's blaze in the tent camp may have been caused by secondary explosions, possibly from Palestinian militants' weapons. The results of Israel's initial probe into the fire were issued on Tuesday, with military spokesman Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari saying the cause of the fire was still under investigation but that the munitions used - targeting what the army said was a position with two senior Hamas militants - were too small to be the source.\n\nThe strike or the subsequent fire could also have ignited fuel, cooking gas canisters or other materials in the camp. The blaze killed 45 Palestinians, according to Gaza health officials' count. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the fire was the result of a \"tragic mishap\".\n\nIsrael's assault on Rafah, launched on May 6, has caused more than 1 million people to flee the city, the UN agency helping Palestinian refugees said Tuesday. Most had already been displaced multiple times in the nearly eight-month war between Israel and Hamas. Families are now scattered across makeshift tent camps and other war-ravaged areas.\n\nThe strikes over the past few days have hit areas west of Rafah, which had not been ordered by the military to evacuate. Israeli ground troops and tanks have been operating in eastern Rafah, in central parts of the city, and along the Gaza-Egypt border.\n\nShelling late on Monday and early Tuesday hit Rafah's western Tel al-Sultan district, killing at least 16 people, the Palestinian Civil Defence and the Palestinian Red Crescent said. Seven of the dead were in tents next to a UN facility about 200m from the site of Sunday night's strike and fire.\n\n\"It was a night of horror,\" said Abdel-Rahman Abu Ismail, a Palestinian from Gaza City who has been sheltering in Tel al-Sultan since December. He said he heard \"constant sounds\" of explosions overnight and into Tuesday, with fighter jets and drones flying over the area.\n\nHe said it reminded him of the Israeli invasion of his neighbourhood of Shijaiyah in Gaza City, where Israel launched a heavy bombing campaign before sending in ground forces in late 2023. \"We saw this before.\"\n\nThe United States and other allies of Israel have warned against a full-fledged offensive in the city, with the Biden administration saying that would cross a red line and refusing to provide offensive arms for such an undertaking. On Friday, the International Court of Justice called on Israel to halt its Rafah offensive, an order it has no power to enforce.\n\nOn Tuesday afternoon, an Israeli drone strike hit tents near a field hospital by the Mediterranean coast west of Rafah, killing at least 21 people, including 13 women, the Gaza Health Ministry said.\n\nA witness, Ahmed Nassar, said his four cousins and some of their husbands and children were killed in the strike and that a number of tents were destroyed or damaged. Most of those living there had fled from the same neighbourhood in Gaza City earlier in the war.\n\n\"They have nothing to do with anything,\" he said.\n\nNetanyahu has vowed to press ahead, saying Israeli forces must enter Rafah to dismantle Hamas and return hostages taken in the October 7 attack that triggered the war.\n\nIn its investigation of Sunday's deadly strike and fire, the Israeli military released satellite photos of what it said was a Hamas rocket launch position about 40m from an area of sheds that was targeted. In the photo, the alleged launcher itself did not appear to have been struck.\n\nHe said Israeli warplanes used the smallest munition possible - two munitions with 17kg warheads. \"Our munition alone could not have ignited a fire of this size.\"\n\nHagari said that the fire was \"a devastating incident which we did not expect\" and said it ignited due to \"unforeseen circumstances\".\n\nStill, the strikes have triggered a flight of people from areas west of Rafah. Sayed al-Masri, a Rafah resident, said many families were heading to the crowded Muwasi area or to Khan Younis, a southern city that suffered heavy damage during months of fighting.\n\nGaza's Health Ministry said two medical facilities in Tel al-Sultan are out of service because of intense bombing nearby. Medical Aid for Palestinians, a charity operating throughout the territory, said the Tel al-Sultan medical centre and the Indonesian Field Hospital were under lockdown, with medics, patients and displaced people trapped inside.\n\nMost of Gaza's hospitals are no longer functioning. Rafah's Kuwait Hospital shut down Monday after a strike near its entrance killed two health workers.\n\nA spokesperson for the World Health Organisation said the casualties from Sunday's strike and fire \"absolutely overwhelmed\" field hospitals in the area, which were already running short on supplies to treat severe burns.\n\n\"That requires intensive care, that requires electricity, that requires high-level medical services,\" Dr Margaret Harris told reporters in Geneva. \"Increasingly, we are struggling to even have the high-level skilled doctors and nurses because they've been displaced.\"\n\nThe fighting in Rafah has made it nearly impossible for humanitarian groups to import and distribute aid to southern Gaza.\n\nThe Israeli military says it has allowed hundreds of trucks to enter through the nearby Kerem Shalom crossing since the start of its operation, but aid groups say it's extremely difficult to access that aid on the Gaza side because of the fighting.\n\nThe UN says it has only been able to collect aid from around 170 trucks over the past three weeks via Kerem Shalom. Smaller amounts of aid are entering through two crossings in the north and by sea through a US-built floating pier, but it's nowhere near the 600 trucks a day that aid groups say are needed.", "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/gaza-civil-defence-says-21-dead-in-new-israeli-strike-on-gaza-camp/article_ae86023e-740e-5214-b24f-3305650bafe4.html", "title": "Gaza civil defence says 21 dead in new Israeli strike on Gaza camp", "body": "A civil defence official in the Hamas-run Gaza Strip said an Israeli strike on a displacement camp west of Rafah on Tuesday killed at least 21 people, days after a similar strike that sparked global outrage.\n\nMohammad al-Mughayyir said they were killed in an \"occupation strike targeting the tents of displaced people west of Rafah.\" Hamas said an Israeli strike had caused \"dozens of martyrs and wounded\" in the area.\n\nIt came as Israeli tanks penetrated the heart of Rafah, according to Palestinian officials, despite widespread condemnation over an air strike on a crowded camp in the southern Gaza city that killed 45 people two days earlier.\n\nIsraeli tanks were \"stationed on the Al-Awda roundabout in the centre of the city of Rafah\", one witness said.\n\nA Palestinian security source said tanks were in central Rafah, where Israeli troops launched a controversial ground assault earlier this month.\n\n\"People are currently inside their homes because anyone who moves is being shot at by Israeli drones,\" one resident, Abdel Khatib, said.\n\nWith an emergency United Nations Security Council meeting at 1915 GMT due to discuss Sunday's strike on the displaced camp, the situation remains tense in Rafah.\n\nIn a statement issued hours before the meeting, Israel's military said the weapons used in Sunday's strike \"could not\" have caused the deadly blaze in the Rafah camp.\n\n\"Our munition alone could not have ignited a fire of this size,\" said military spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari.\n\nSunday evening's strike, which medics said also wounded hundreds of civilians, drew worldwide condemnation.\n\nThe sight of the charred carnage, blackened corpses and children being rushed to hospitals led UN chief Antonio Guterres to declare that \"there is no safe place in Gaza. This horror must stop.\"\n\nIsrael's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called the strike a \"tragic accident\" but also vowed to continue the campaign to destroy Hamas over the October 7 attack and bring home all the hostages.\n\nMore air strikes and shelling rained down overnight on besieged Gaza -- including the Tal al-Sultan area where the displacement camp went up in flames near a facility of the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, UNRWA.\n\n\"The situation is very dangerous,\" said resident Faten Jouda, 30. \"We didn't sleep all night. There was random bombing from all directions, including artillery shelling and air bombardment as well as firing from aircraft.\n\n\"We saw everyone fleeing again,\" she told AFP. \"We too will go now and head to Al-Mawasi because we fear for our lives,\" she said of a nearby coastal area Israel has declared a safe \"humanitarian zone\".\n\nUNRWA said one million civilians had fled Rafah since Israel launched its assault on the city in early May despite a chorus of international warnings.\n\n\"This happened with nowhere safe to go & amidst bombardments, lack of food & water, piles of waste & unsuitable living conditions,\" it posted on X.\n\n- Palestinian statehood -\n\nMore than seven months into the deadliest Gaza war, Israel has faced ever louder global opposition, as well as cases before two international courts based in the Netherlands.\n\nIn a landmark political move on Tuesday, Ireland, Norway and Spain formally recognised the State of Palestine, a step so far taken by more than 140 UN members but few Western governments.\n\nSpanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said the recognition was \"not only a matter of historic justice... it is also an essential requirement if we are all to achieve peace\".\n\n\"It is the only way to move towards the solution that we all recognise as the only possible way to achieve a peaceful future: that of a Palestinian state living side by side with the State of Israel in peace and security.\"\n\nIrish Prime Minister Simon Harris said the aim was to keep Middle East peace hopes alive, and urged Israel to \"stop the humanitarian catastrophe\" in Gaza.\n\nIsrael has slammed the recognition as a \"reward\" for the Islamist Hamas movement, and recalled its diplomatic envoys from Madrid, Dublin and Oslo.\n\nForeign Minister Israel Katz went further on Tuesday and launched an attack on Sanchez on X, telling him that \"you are a partner to incitement to genocide of the Jewish people\".\n\nSpanish Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Albares said the three governments would \"issue a coordinated response\" to Israel which he said would be \"calm but firm\".\n\n- 'Hell on Earth' -\n\nThe Gaza war was sparked by Hamas's October 7 attack on southern Israel, which resulted in the deaths of more than 1,170 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nMilitants also took 252 hostages, 121 of whom remain in Gaza, including 37 the army says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory offensive has killed at least 36,096 people in Gaza, mostly civilians, according to the territory's health ministry.\n\nSunday night's attack that killed dozens in the displaced persons camp was targeting two senior Hamas members, the Israeli military said.\n\nIt said aircraft \"struck a Hamas compound\" and killed Yassin Rabia and Khaled Nagar, senior officials for the group in the occupied West Bank.\n\nThe strike came hours after Hamas had fired a barrage of rockets towards Tel Aviv, with most being intercepted.\n\nThe civilian death toll in the Gaza camp prompted a wave of condemnation, with Palestinians and many Arab countries calling it a \"massacre\".\n\nUNRWA chief Philippe Lazzarini said Monday that \"the images from last night are testament to how Rafah has turned into hell on Earth\".\n\nEU foreign policy chief Joseph Borrell said he was \"horrified\" and French President Emmanuel Macron said he was \"outraged\".\n\nA US National Security Council spokesperson said Israel \"must take every precaution possible to protect civilians\".\n\nburs-jd/srm/dv\n\nMore from this section\n\nClosing arguments, jury instructions and maybe a verdict? {"uri": "8150477235", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "20:35:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T20:35:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T20:35:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2953468-global-outcry-over-rafah-offensive-amidst-recognitions-of-palestinian-state", "title": "Global Outcry Over Rafah Offensive Amidst Recognitions Of Palestinian State | Law-Order", "body": "The international community expressed outrage after Israel's military denied tank shelling civilians in Rafah, claiming to target Hamas operatives. Despite global condemnation, including from the ICJ, Spanish, Norwegian, and Irish recognition of a Palestinian state further isolated Israel. Efforts for a ceasefire were hindered as heavy fighting continued.\n\nIsrael's military denied striking a tent camp west of the city of Rafah on Tuesday after Gaza health authorities said Israeli tank shelling had killed at least 21 people there, in what Israel has designated a civilian evacuation zone. Earlier, defying an appeal from the International Court of Justice (ICJ), Israeli tanks advanced to the heart of Rafah for the first time after a night of heavy bombardment, while Spain, Ireland and Norway officially recognised a Palestinian state, a move that further deepened Israel's international isolation.\n\nThe United States, Israel's closest ally, reiterated its opposition to a major Israeli ground offensive in Rafah but said it did not believe such an operation was underway. Two days after an Israeli airstrike on another camp stirred global condemnation, Gaza emergency services said four tank shells hit a cluster of tents in Al-Mawasi, a coastal strip that Israel had advised civilians in Rafah to move to for safety.\n\nAt least 12 of the dead were women, according to medical officials in the Hamas militant-run Palestinian enclave. But Israel's military later said in a statement: \"Contrary to the reports from the last few hours, the IDF (Israel Defence Forces) did not strike in the Humanitarian Area in Al-Mawasi.\"\n\nTuesday's incident in Al-Mawasi occurred in an area designated by Israel as an expanded humanitarian zone. Israel had urged Palestinian civilians in Rafah, including around one million displaced by the almost eight-month-old war, to evacuate there when it launched its incursion in early May. In central Rafah, tanks and armoured vehicles mounted with machine guns were spotted near Al-Awda mosque, a city landmark, witnesses told Reuters. The Israeli military said its forces continued to operate in the Rafah area, without commenting on reported advances into the city centre.\n\nOUTRAGE International unease over Israel's three-week-old Rafah offensive has turned to outrage after an attack on Sunday set off a blaze in a tent camp in a western district of the city, killing at least 45 people.\n\nIsrael said it had targeted two senior Hamas operatives and had not intended to cause civilian casualties. Global leaders voiced horror at the fire in a designated \"humanitarian zone\" of Rafah where families uprooted by fighting elsewhere had sought shelter, and urged the implementation of a World Court order last week for a halt to Israel's assault.\n\nThe Israeli military said it was investigating the possibility that munitions stored near a compound targeted by Sunday's airstrike may have ignited and touched off the blaze. Residents said Rafah's Tel Al-Sultan neighbourhood, the scene of Sunday's night-time strike in which tents and shelters were set ablaze as families settled down to sleep, was still being bombarded.\n\n\"Tank shells are falling everywhere in Tel Al-Sultan. Many families have fled their houses in western Rafah under fire throughout the night,\" one resident told Reuters via a chat app. The Biden administration said on Tuesday it was closely monitoring the probe into Sunday's air strike. U.S. Vice President Kamala Harris said: \"The word tragic doesn't even begin to describe\" what happened on Sunday.\n\nBut White House spokesman John Kirby said there was nothing in the incidents on Sunday or on Tuesday that would prompt the United States to halt its military aid to Israel. U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres added his voice to the chorus of condemnation of Sunday's strike and again urged Israel to allow \"the immediate, safe and unhindered delivery of humanitarian assistance to those in need\".\n\nIn a further blow to aid efforts, a part of the U.S. military's pier off Gaza's coast has broken off, probably due to bad weather, rendering it temporarily inoperable, two U.S. officials said. The United Nations has transported 137 trucks of aid from the pier since it began operations two weeks ago. Spain, Norway and Ireland said they hoped their decision to recognise a Palestinian state would speed up efforts towards securing a ceasefire in Israel's war against Hamas militants, which has reduced much of the densely populated territory to rubble.\n\nEgypt is again trying in tandem with Qatar and the U.S. to revive talks on a ceasefire and the release of hostages held by Hamas, but efforts have been hampered by Israel's assault on Rafah, Cairo's state-affiliated Al-Qahera News TV channel said on Tuesday, citing a senior official. Around one million people - many repeatedly uprooted by shifting waves of the war - have fled the Israeli offensive in Rafah since early May, the U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees (UNRWA) reported on Tuesday.\n\nTANKS Israel seized control of the Rafah border crossing with Egypt three weeks ago. Its tanks then entered some eastern districts of the city but had previously not rumbled into the centre in full force.\n\nOn Tuesday, witnesses also reported gun battles between Israeli troops and Hamas-led fighters in the area of the Zurub hilltop in western Rafah. More than 36,000 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's offensive, Gaza's health ministry says. Israel launched its air and ground war after Hamas-led militants attacked southern Israeli communities on Oct. 7, killing around 1,200 people and seizing more than 250 hostages, according to Israeli tallies.\n\nIsrael says it wants to root out the last major intact formations of Hamas fighters hunkered down in Rafah and rescue hostages it says are being held in the area.\n\n(This story has not "title": "Gaza civil defence says 21 dead in new Israeli strike on Gaza camp", "body": "Palestinians flee the area of Tal al-Sultan in Rafah with their belongings following renewed Israeli strikes in the city in the southern Gaza Strip on May 28, 2024\n\nA civil defence official in the Hamas-run Gaza Strip said an Israeli strike on a displacement camp west of Rafah on Tuesday killed at least 21 people, days after a similar strike that sparked global outrage.\n\nMohammad al-Mughayyir said they were killed in an \"occupation strike targeting the tents of displaced people west of Rafah.\" Hamas said an Israeli strike had caused \"dozens of martyrs and wounded\" in the area.\n\nIt came as Israeli tanks penetrated the heart of Rafah, according to Palestinian officials, despite widespread condemnation over an air strike on a crowded camp in the southern Gaza city that killed 45 people two days earlier.\n\nIsraeli tanks were \"stationed on the Al-Awda roundabout in the centre of the city of Rafah\", one witness said.\n\nA Palestinian security source said tanks were in central Rafah, where Israeli troops launched a controversial ground assault earlier this month.\n\n\"People are currently inside their homes because anyone who moves is being shot at by Israeli drones,\" one resident, Abdel Khatib, said.\n\nWith an emergency United Nations Security Council meeting at 1915 GMT due to discuss Sunday's strike on the displaced camp, the situation remains tense in Rafah.\n\nIn a statement issued hours before the meeting, Israel's military said the weapons used in Sunday's strike \"could not\" have caused the deadly blaze in the Rafah camp.\n\n\"Our munition alone could not have ignited a fire of this size,\" said military spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari.\n\nSunday evening's strike, which medics said also wounded hundreds of civilians, drew worldwide condemnation.\n\nThe sight of the charred carnage, blackened corpses and children being rushed to hospitals led UN chief Antonio Guterres to declare that \"there is no safe place in Gaza. This horror must stop.\"\n\nIsrael's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called the strike a \"tragic accident\" but also vowed to continue the campaign to destroy Hamas over the October 7 attack and bring home all the hostages.\n\nMore air strikes and shelling rained down overnight on besieged Gaza -- including the Tal al-Sultan area where the displacement camp went up in flames near a facility of the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, UNRWA.\n\n\"The situation is very dangerous,\" said resident Faten Jouda, 30. \"We didn't sleep all night. There was random bombing from all directions, including artillery shelling and air bombardment as well as firing from aircraft.\n\n\"We saw everyone fleeing again,\" she told AFP. \"We too will go now and head to Al-Mawasi because we fear for our lives,\" she said of a nearby coastal area Israel has declared a safe \"humanitarian zone\".\n\nUNRWA said one million civilians had fled Rafah since Israel launched its assault on the city in early May despite a chorus of international warnings.\n\n\"This happened with nowhere safe to go & amidst bombardments, lack of food & water, piles of waste & unsuitable living conditions,\" it posted on X.\n\n- Palestinian statehood -\n\nMore than seven months into the deadliest Gaza war, Israel has faced ever louder global opposition, as well as cases before two international courts based in the Netherlands.\n\nMore from this section Nations Fail to Agree on Treaty on Preventing Next Pandemic Modi's 'Mujra For Vote Bank' Attack On INDIA Bloc; Kejriwal Schools Pak Neta 2024 Lok Sabha Polls Hicksville veteran awarded Purple Heart posthumously\n\nIn a landmark political move on Tuesday, Ireland, Norway and Spain formally recognised the State of Palestine, a step so far taken by more than 140 UN members but few Western governments.\n\nSpanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said the recognition was \"not only a matter of historic justice... it is also an essential requirement if we are all to achieve peace\".\n\n\"It is the only way to move towards the solution that we all recognise as the only possible way to achieve a peaceful future: that of a Palestinian state living side by side with the State of Israel in peace and security.\"\n\nIrish Prime Minister Simon Harris said the aim was to keep Middle East peace hopes alive, and urged Israel to \"stop the humanitarian catastrophe\" in Gaza.\n\nIsrael has slammed the recognition as a \"reward\" for the Islamist Hamas movement, and recalled its diplomatic envoys from Madrid, Dublin and Oslo.\n\nForeign Minister Israel Katz went further on Tuesday and launched an attack on Sanchez on X, telling him that \"you are a partner to incitement to genocide of the Jewish people\".\n\nSpanish Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Albares said the three governments would \"issue a coordinated response\" to Israel which he said would be \"calm but firm\".\n\n- 'Hell on Earth' -\n\nThe Gaza war was sparked by Hamas's October 7 attack on southern Israel, which resulted in the deaths of more than 1,170 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nMilitants also took 252 hostages, 121 of whom remain in Gaza, including 37 the army says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory offensive has killed at least 36,096 people in Gaza, mostly civilians, according to the territory's health ministry.\n\nSunday night's attack that killed dozens in the displaced persons camp was targeting two senior Hamas members, the Israeli military said.\n\nIt said aircraft \"struck a Hamas compound\" and killed Yassin Rabia and Khaled Nagar, senior officials for the group in the occupied West Bank.\n\nThe strike came hours after Hamas had fired a barrage of rockets towards Tel Aviv, with most being intercepted.\n\nThe civilian death toll in the Gaza camp prompted a wave of condemnation, with Palestinians and many Arab countries calling it a \"massacre\".\n\nUNRWA chief Philippe Lazzarini said Monday that \"the images from last night are testament to how Rafah has turned into hell on Earth\".\n\nEU foreign policy chief Joseph Borrell said he was \"horrified\" and French President Emmanuel Macron said he was \"outraged\".\n\nA US National Security Council spokesperson said Israel \"must take every precaution possible to protect
