{"uri": "8150218948", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "16:53:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T16:53:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T16:53:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.yakimaherald.com/news/nation_and_world/nation/the-latest-fighting-escalates-in-rafah-as-israel-pushes-ahead-with-its-offensive/article_beb8349b-aa65-5380-998c-f0fafdaacf37.html", "title": "The Latest | Fighting escalates in Rafah as Israel pushes ahead with its offensive", "body": "Palestinians fleeing from the southern Gaza city of Rafah during an Israeli ground and air offensive in the city on Tuesday, May 28, 2024.\n\nPalestinian residents of the southern Gaza city of Rafah have reported an escalation of fighting Tuesday as Israeli forces pressed their assault on the border town once seen as the territory's last refuge.\n\nIsrael says it is carrying out limited operations in eastern Rafah along the Gaza-Egypt border, as the United States and other allies of Israel have warned against a full-fledged offensive in the city.\n\nIsraeli leaders say their forces must enter Rafah to dismantle Hamas and return hostages taken in the Oct. 7 attack that triggered the war.\n\nFighting in Rafah has caused nearly 1 million Palestinians to flee, most of whom had already been displaced in the war between Israel and Hamas. They now seek refuge in squalid tent camps and other war-ravaged areas, where they lack shelter, food, water and other essentials for survival, the U.N. says.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to the Health Ministry, which doesn't distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nIsrael launched its war in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack in which militants stormed into southern Israel, killed some 1,200 people -- mostly civilians -- and abducted about 250. Israel says around 100 hostages are still captive in Gaza, along with the bodies of around 30 more.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Spain, Norway and Ireland formally recognize a Palestinian state as EU rift with Israel widens.\n\n-- Netanyahu says deadly Israeli strike in Rafah over the weekend was the result of a \"tragic mishap.\"\n\n-- As Israel attacks Rafah, Palestinians are living in tents and scrounging for food.\n\n-- An Israeli strike in southern Lebanon kills 2 people near a hospital, officials say.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of the war in Gaza at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war.\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nWOMEN AND GIRLS SUFFERING THE MOST IN GAZA, SAYS HEAD OF U.N. AGENCY FOR GENDER EQUALITY\n\nUNITED NATIONS - The head of the United Nations agency promoting gender equality is demanding a halt to the war in Gaza, saying women and girls are suffering the most.\n\nSima Bahous, executive director of U.N. Women, said Tuesday more than 10,000 women have been killed in the seven months of fighting - including scores of women and children \"horrifically killed\" by an Israeli airstrike Monday while sleeping in tents in what was supposed to be a safe zone in Gaza's southern city of Rafah.\n\nBahous told a U.N. Security Council meeting it is \"for all women and girls caught in this conflict that we demand a permanent cease-fire, unhindered humanitarian access, the release of all hostages, the determined pursuit of peace, and a two-state solution.\"\n\n\"This war must stop because women and girls are bearing the brunt of it,\" Bahous told the meeting on the role of women and youth in promoting international peace and security.\n\nISRAELI ARMY SAYS FIRE IN RAFAH AIRSTRIKE WAS CAUSED BY SECONDARY BLAST\n\nJERUSALEM -- The Israeli military says an initial investigation into a strike that sparked a deadly fire in a tent camp in the southern Gaza city of Rafah has found the blaze was caused by a secondary explosion.\n\nRear Adm. Daniel Hagari, the chief military spokesman, said Tuesday that the military fired two 17-kilogram (37-pound) munitions that targeted two senior Hamas militants. He said the munitions would have been too small to ignite a fire on their own and that the military is looking into the possibility that weapons were stored in the area.\n\nThe strike or subsequent fire also could have ignited fuel, cooking gas canisters or other materials in the densely populated tent camp housing displaced people.\n\nPalestinian health officials say at least 45 people, around half of them women and children, were killed in Sunday's strike.\n\nThe strike caused widespread outrage, including from some of Israel's closest allies. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said it was the result of a \"tragic mishap.\"\n\nISRAELI STRIKES ON RAFAH KILL AT LEAST 16 PALESTINIANS, FIRST RESPONDERS SAY\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip -- Israeli strikes on Rafah have killed at least 16 Palestinians overnight, first responders said Tuesday, as residents reported an escalation of fighting in the southern Gaza city.\n\nAn Israeli incursion launched earlier this month has caused nearly 1 million to flee from Rafah, most of whom have already been displaced in the war between Israel and Hamas, and who are now seeking refuge in squalid tent camps and war-ravaged areas.\n\nThe latest strikes occurred in the same area where Israel targeted what it said was a Hamas compound on Sunday night. That strike ignited a fire in a camp for displaced Palestinians and killed at least 45 people, according to local health officials, sparking worldwide outrage.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said there was a \"tragic mishap\" on Sunday and the military said it was investigating.\n\nThe latest strikes killed a total of 16 people in the Tel al-Sultan neighborhood in northwest Rafah, according to the Palestinian Civil Defense and the Palestinian Red Crescent.\n\nNORWAY FORMALLY RECOGNIZES A PALESTINIAN STATE\n\nCOPENHAGEN, Denmark -- Norway on Tuesday formally recognized a Palestinian state with the Scandinavian foreign minister calling it \"a milestone in the relationship between Norway and Palestine.\"\n\nForeign Minister Espen Barth Eide said \"the recognition is a strong expression of support for moderate forces in both countries.\"\n\nHowever, \"it is regrettable that the Israeli government shows no signs of engaging constructively,\" Barth Eide said. \"The international community must increase its political and economic support for Palestine and continue the work for a two-state solution.\"\n\nLast week, Norway, along with Spain and Ireland, said in a coordinated effort that they were recognizing a Palestinian state.\n\nSPAIN WILL BEGIN RECOGNIZING A PALESTINIAN STATE\n\nMADRID -- Spain moved to formally recognize a Palestinian state with Ireland and Norway to follow suit on Tuesday in a coordinated effort by the three western European nations. Israel slammed the diplomatic move that will have no immediate impact on its grinding war in Gaza but adds to international pressure to soften its devastating response to October's Hamas-led attack.\n\nIsraeli Foreign Minister Israel Katz accused Spain of \"being complicit in inciting genocide against Jews and war crimes\" and told the country that its consulate in Jerusalem will not be allowed to help Palestinians.\n\nPrime Minister Pedro S\u00e1nchez, who announced his country's decision before parliament last week, has spent months touring European and Middle Eastern countries to garner support for recognition and a cease-fire in Gaza.\n\nRelations between the EU and Israel nosedived Monday, the eve of the diplomatic recognition EU members Ireland and Spain, with Madrid insisting that sanctions should be considered against Israel for its continued deadly attacks in southern Gaza's city of Rafah.\n\nIRANIAN PARLIAMENT REELECTS HARD-LINER QALIBAF AS ITS SPEAKER\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates -- Iran's parliament reelected hard-liner Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf on Tuesday as its speaker, reaffirming its hard-right makeup in the wake of a helicopter crash that killed the country's president and foreign minister.\n\nOf 287 lawmakers voting Tuesday, 198 backed Qalibaf to retain the position he first took in 2021. He initially became speaker following a string of failed presidential bids and 12 years as the leader of Iran's capital city. Many, however, know Qalibaf for his support as a Revolutionary Guard general for a violent crackdown on Iranian university students in 1999. He also reportedly ordered live gunfire to be used against Iranian students in 2003 while serving as the country's police chief.", "source": {"uri": "yakimaherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8150457631", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "20:16:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T20:16:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T20:15:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/world-news/2024/05/28/israeli-strikes-continue-near-gazas-rafah/", "title": "Israeli strikes continue near Gaza's Rafah", "body": "The tent camp inferno has drawn widespread outrage, including from some of Israel's closest allies, over the military's expanding offensive.\n\nRenewed Israeli shelling and strikes have killed at least 37 people, most of them sheltering in tents, outside the southern Gaza city of Rafah, according to witnesses, first responders and hospital officials.\n\nThe strikes overnight and on Tuesday pummelled the same area where strikes had triggered a deadly fire that swept through a camp for displaced Palestinian, they said.\n\nThe tent camp inferno has drawn widespread international outrage, including from some of Israel's closest allies, over the military's expanding offensive into Rafah.\n\nAnd in a sign of Israel's growing isolation on the world stage, Spain, Norway and Ireland formally recognised a Palestinian state on Tuesday.\n\nThe Israeli military suggested Sunday's blaze in the tent camp may have been caused by secondary explosions, possibly from Palestinian militants' weapons.\n\nThe results of Israel's initial probe into the fire were issued on Tuesday, with military spokesman Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari saying the cause of the fire was still under investigation but that the munitions used - targeting what the army said was a position with two senior Hamas militants - were too small to be the source.\n\nThe strike or the subsequent fire could also have ignited fuel, cooking gas canisters or other materials in the camp.\n\nThe blaze killed 45 Palestinians, according to Gaza health officials' count.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the fire was the result of a \"tragic mishap\".\n\nIsrael's assault on Rafah, launched on May 6, has caused more than one million people to flee the city, the UN agency helping Palestinian refugees said on Tuesday.\n\nMost had already been displaced multiple times in the nearly eight-month war between Israel and Hamas.\n\nFamilies are now scattered across makeshift tent camps and other war-ravaged areas.\n\nThe strikes over the past few days have hit areas west of Rafah, which had not been ordered by the military to evacuate.\n\nIsraeli ground troops and tanks have been operating in eastern Rafah, in central parts of the city, and along the Gaza-Egypt border.\n\nShelling late on Monday and early on Tuesday hit Rafah's western Tel al-Sultan district, killing at least 16 people, the Palestinian Civil Defence and the Palestinian Red Crescent said.\n\nSeven of the dead were in tents next to a UN facility about 200 metres from the site of Sunday night's strike and fire.\n\n\"It was a night of horror,\" said Abdel-Rahman Abu Ismail, a Palestinian from Gaza City who has been sheltering in Tel al-Sultan since December.\n\nHe said he heard \"constant sounds\" of explosions overnight and into Tuesday, with fighter jets and drones flying over the area.\n\nHe said it reminded him of the Israeli invasion of his neighbourhood of Shijaiyah in Gaza City, where Israel launched a heavy bombing campaign before sending in ground forces in late 2023.\n\n\"We saw this before,\" he said.\n\nThe United States and other allies of Israel have warned against a full-fledged offensive in the city, with the Biden administration saying that would cross a red line and refusing to provide offensive arms for such an undertaking.\n\nOn Friday, the International Court of Justice called on Israel to halt its Rafah offensive, an order it has no power to enforce.\n\nOn Tuesday afternoon, an Israeli drone strike hit tents near a field hospital by the Mediterranean coast west of Rafah, killing at least 21 people, including 13 women, the Gaza Health Ministry said.\n\nA witness, Ahmed Nassar, said his four cousins and some of their husbands and children were killed in the strike and that a number of tents were destroyed or damaged.\n\nMost of those living there had fled from the same neighbourhood in Gaza City earlier in the war.\n\n\"They have nothing to do with anything,\" he said.\n\nMr Netanyahu has vowed to press ahead, saying Israeli forces must enter Rafah to dismantle Hamas and return hostages taken in the October 7 attack that triggered the war.\n\nIn its investigation of Sunday's deadly strike and fire, the Israeli military released satellite photos of what it said was a Hamas rocket launch position about 40 metres from an area of sheds that was targeted.\n\nIn the photo, the alleged launcher itself did not appear to have been struck.\n\nRear Admiral Hagari said Israeli warplanes used the smallest munition possible - two munitions with 17-kilogram warheads.\n\n\"Our munition alone could not have ignited a fire of this size,\" he said.\n\nRear Admiral Hagari said that the fire was \"a devastating incident which we did not expect\" and said it ignited due to \"unforeseen circumstances\".\n\nStill, the strikes have triggered a flight of people from areas west of Rafah.\n\nSayed al-Masri, a Rafah resident, said many families were heading to the crowded Muwasi area or to Khan Younis, a southern city that suffered heavy damage during months of fighting.\n\n\"The situation is worsening\" in Rafah, al-Masri said.\n\nGaza's Health Ministry said two medical facilities in Tel al-Sultan are out of service because of intense bombing nearby.\n\nMedical Aid for Palestinians, a charity operating throughout the territory, said the Tel al-Sultan medical centre and the Indonesian Field Hospital were under lockdown, with medics, patients and displaced people trapped inside.\n\nMost of Gaza's hospitals are no longer functioning.\n\nRafah's Kuwait Hospital shut down on Monday after a strike near its entrance killed two health workers.\n\nA spokesperson for the World Health Organisation said the casualties from Sunday's strike and fire \"absolutely overwhelmed\" field hospitals in the area, which were already running short on supplies to treat severe burns.\n\n\"That requires intensive care, that requires electricity, that requires high-level medical services,\" Dr Margaret Harris told reporters in Geneva.\n\n\"Increasingly, we are struggling to even have the high-level skilled doctors and nurses because they've been displaced.\"\n\nThe war began when Hamas and other militants burst into southern Israel in a surprise attack on October 7, killing some 1,200 civilians and abducting around 250.\n\nMore than 100 were released during a week-long ceasefire in November in exchange for Palestinians imprisoned by Israel.\n\nIsrael responded to the attack with a massive air, land and sea offensive that has killed at least 36,096 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians in its count.\n\nAround 80% of Gaza's population of 2.3 million has been displaced and United Nations officials say parts of the territory are experiencing famine.\n\nThe fighting in Rafah has made it nearly impossible for humanitarian groups to import and distribute aid to southern Gaza.\n\nThe Israeli military says it has allowed hundreds of trucks to enter through the nearby Kerem Shalom crossing since the start of its operation, but aid groups say it is extremely difficult to access that aid on the Gaza side because of the fighting.\n\nThe UN says it has only been able to collect aid from around 170 trucks over the past three weeks {"uri": "2024-05-371262462", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "19:29:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T19:29:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T19:14:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/israel-again-bombs-rafah-security-090120112.html", "title": "Civil defence says 21 dead in new strike on Gaza camp that Israel denies", "body": "A civil defence official in Hamas-run Gaza said an Israeli strike on a displacement camp west of Rafah on Tuesday killed at least 21 people, after a similar strike that sparked global outrage.\n\nIsrael denied carrying out the latest reported strike, which occurred ahead of a UN Security Council meeting to discuss a Sunday strike which Palestinian officials said killed 45 people.\n\nDespite mounting concerns over the civilian toll of its war on Hamas, Israel has shown no signs of changing course and international efforts aimed at securing a ceasefire remain stalled.\n\nIn the latest bloodshed, Gaza civil defence agency official Mohammad al-Mughayyir said 21 people were killed in an \"occupation strike targeting the tents of displaced people\" in west Rafah. Hamas said an Israeli strike on the area caused \"dozens of martyrs and wounded\".\n\nIsrael's army rejected the allegations, saying it \"did not strike\" the designated humanitarian area in Al-Mawasi.\n\nIn Rafah, residents and a Palestinian security source said Israeli tanks had now penetrated the heart of the southern city.\n\n\"People are currently inside their homes because anyone who moves is being shot at by Israeli drones,\" one resident, Abdel Khatib, said.\n\n- 'Random bombing' -\n\nAn emergency Security Council meeting is due to discuss Sunday's deadly strike from 1915 GMT.\n\nAhead of the meeting, Israel's military said the weapons used in that strike \"could not\" have caused the deadly camp blaze.\n\n\"Our munition alone could not have ignited a fire of this size,\" said its spokesperson, Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari.\n\nSunday evening's strike, which medics said also wounded hundreds of civilians, drew worldwide condemnation.\n\nThe sight of the charred carnage, blackened corpses and children being rushed to hospitals led UN chief Antonio Guterres to declare that \"there is no safe place in Gaza. This horror must stop.\"\n\nIsrael's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu referred to the strike as a \"tragic accident\" but affirmed the continuation of the campaign to destroy Hamas over the October 7 attack and to bring home all the hostages.\n\nPalestinian militant group Islamic Jihad on Tuesday released a video showing an Israeli hostage alive and held in Gaza, identified by Israeli media as Sasha Trupanov, 28.\n\nAir strikes and shelling had battered Gaza overnight Monday-Tuesday -- including the Tal al-Sultan area where the displacement camp went up in flames near a facility of the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, UNRWA.\n\nFaten Jouda, a 30-year-old resident, described the situation.\n\n\"There was random bombing from all directions... We saw everyone fleeing again,\" she told AFP. \"We too will go now and head to Al-Mawasi because we fear for our lives.\"\n\n- Palestinian statehood -\n\nUNRWA said one million civilians had fled Rafah since Israel launched its assault on the city in early May despite a chorus of international warnings.\n\nNearly eight months into the deadliest Gaza war, Israel has faced ever louder opposition, as well as cases before two Netherlands-based international courts.\n\nIn a landmark move on Tuesday, Ireland, Norway and Spain formally recognised the State of Palestine, a step so far taken by more than 140 UN members but few Western governments.\n\nSpanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said the recognition was \"not only a matter of historic justice... it is also an essential requirement if we are all to achieve peace\".\n\nIrish Prime Minister Simon Harris said the aim was to keep Middle East peace hopes alive, and urged Israel to \"stop the humanitarian catastrophe\" in Gaza.\n\nIsrael has slammed the recognition as a \"reward\" for Hamas, and recalled its diplomatic envoys from Madrid, Dublin and Oslo.\n\nSpanish Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Albares said the three governments would \"issue a coordinated response\" to Israel which would be \"calm but firm\".\n\nThe Gaza war was sparked by Hamas's October 7 attack on southern Israel, which resulted in the deaths of 1,189 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on the latest Israeli official figures.\n\nMilitants also took 252 hostages, 121 of whom remain in Gaza, including 37 the army says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory offensive has killed at least 36,096 people in Gaza, mostly civilians, according to the territory's health ministry.\n\n- 'Hell on Earth' -\n\nSunday night's attack that killed dozens in the displaced persons camp was targeting two senior Hamas members, the Israeli military said.\n\nIt said aircraft \"struck a Hamas compound\" and killed Yassin Rabia and Khaled Nagar, senior officials for the group in the occupied West Bank.\n\nThe strike came hours after Hamas fired a barrage of rockets towards Tel Aviv, with most being intercepted.\n\nThe civilian death toll in the Gaza camp prompted a wave of condemnation, with Palestinians and many Arab countries calling it a \"massacre\".\n\nUNRWA chief Philippe Lazzarini said Monday that \"the images from last night are testament to how Rafah has turned into hell on Earth\".\n\nThe United States said it was \"deeply saddened\" over Sunday's Rafah strike and that it would follow Israel's investigation closely.\n\nThe Pentagon, meanwhile, said it had suspended aid deliveries into Gaza by the sea after its temporary pier was damaged by bad weather.\n\nThe World Health Organization said Israel's military offensive in Rafah was already taking a dire health toll in southern Gaza, and if it continues, \"substantial\" increases in deaths could be expected.\n\n\"There are currently 60 WHO trucks (in Egypt) waiting to get into Gaza,\" said Rik Peeperkorn, WHO representative in the Palestinian territories, adding that only three trucks with medical supplies had entered since May 7.\n\nOn the {"uri": "2024-05-371137876", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "16:57:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T16:57:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T16:39:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/national-and-world-news/israel-conflict/the-latest-fighting-escalates-in-rafah-as-israel-pushes-ahead-with-its-offensive/article_a3738cae-3c7c-5efc-badb-46baa2d195d4.html", "title": "The Latest | Fighting escalates in Rafah as Israel pushes ahead with its offensive", "body": "Palestinian residents of the southern Gaza city of Rafah have reported an escalation of fighting Tuesday as Israeli forces pressed their assault on the border town once seen as the territory's last refuge\n\nPalestinian residents of the southern Gaza city of Rafah have reported an escalation of fighting Tuesday as Israeli forces pressed their assault on the border town once seen as the territory's last refuge.\n\nIsrael says it is carrying out limited operations in eastern Rafah along the Gaza-Egypt border, as the United States and other allies of Israel have warned against a full-fledged offensive in the city.\n\nIsraeli leaders say their forces must enter Rafah to dismantle Hamas and return hostages taken in the Oct. 7 attack that triggered the war.\n\nFighting in Rafah has caused nearly 1 million Palestinians to flee, most of whom had already been displaced in the war between Israel and Hamas. They now seek refuge in squalid tent camps and other war-ravaged areas, where they lack shelter, food, water and other essentials for survival, the U.N. says.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to the Health Ministry, which doesn't distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nIsrael launched its war in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack in which militants stormed into southern Israel, killed some 1,200 people -- mostly civilians -- and abducted about 250. Israel says around 100 hostages are still captive in Gaza, along with the bodies of around 30 more.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Spain, Norway and Ireland formally recognize a Palestinian state as EU rift with Israel widens.\n\n-- Netanyahu says deadly Israeli strike in Rafah over the weekend was the result of a \"tragic mishap.\"\n\n-- As Israel attacks Rafah, Palestinians are living in tents and scrounging for food.\n\n-- An Israeli strike in southern Lebanon kills 2 people near a hospital, officials say.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of the war in Gaza at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war.\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nWOMEN AND GIRLS SUFFERING THE MOST IN GAZA, SAYS HEAD OF U.N. AGENCY FOR GENDER EQUALITY\n\nUNITED NATIONS - The head of the United Nations agency promoting gender equality is demanding a halt to the war in Gaza, saying women and girls are suffering the most.\n\nSima Bahous, executive director of U.N. Women, said Tuesday more than 10,000 women have been killed in the seven months of fighting - including scores of women and children \"horrifically killed\" by an Israeli airstrike Monday while sleeping in tents in what was supposed to be a safe zone in Gaza's southern city of Rafah.\n\nBahous told a U.N. Security Council meeting it is \"for all women and girls caught in this conflict that we demand a permanent cease-fire, unhindered humanitarian access, the release of all hostages, the determined pursuit of peace, and a two-state solution.\"\n\n\"This war must stop because women and girls are bearing the brunt of it,\" Bahous told the meeting on the role of women and youth in promoting international peace and security.\n\nISRAELI ARMY SAYS FIRE IN RAFAH AIRSTRIKE WAS CAUSED BY SECONDARY BLAST\n\nJERUSALEM -- The Israeli military says an initial investigation into a strike that sparked a deadly fire in a tent camp in the southern Gaza city of Rafah has found the blaze was caused by a secondary explosion.\n\nRear Adm. Daniel Hagari, the chief military spokesman, said Tuesday that the military fired two 17-kilogram (37-pound) munitions that targeted two senior Hamas militants. He said the munitions would have been too small to ignite a fire on their own and that the military is looking into the possibility that weapons were stored in the area.\n\nThe strike or subsequent fire also could have ignited fuel, cooking gas canisters or other materials in the densely populated tent camp housing displaced people.\n\nPalestinian health officials say at least 45 people, around half of them women and children, were killed in Sunday's strike.\n\nThe strike caused widespread outrage, including from some of Israel's closest allies. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said it was the result of a \"tragic mishap.\"\n\nISRAELI STRIKES ON RAFAH KILL AT LEAST 16 PALESTINIANS, FIRST RESPONDERS SAY\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip -- Israeli strikes on Rafah have killed at least 16 Palestinians overnight, first responders said Tuesday, as residents reported an escalation of fighting in the southern Gaza city.\n\nAn Israeli incursion launched earlier this month has caused nearly 1 million to flee from Rafah, most of whom have already been displaced in the war between Israel and Hamas, and who are now seeking refuge in squalid tent camps and war-ravaged areas.\n\nThe latest strikes occurred in the same area where Israel targeted what it said was a Hamas compound on Sunday night. That strike ignited a fire in a camp for displaced Palestinians and killed at least 45 people, according to local health officials, sparking worldwide outrage.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said there was a \"tragic mishap\" on Sunday and the military said it was investigating.\n\nThe latest strikes killed a total of 16 people in the Tel al-Sultan neighborhood in northwest Rafah, according to the Palestinian Civil Defense and the Palestinian Red Crescent.\n\nNORWAY FORMALLY RECOGNIZES A PALESTINIAN STATE\n\nCOPENHAGEN, Denmark -- Norway on Tuesday formally recognized a Palestinian state with the Scandinavian foreign minister calling it \"a milestone in the relationship between Norway and Palestine.\"\n\nForeign Minister Espen Barth Eide said \"the recognition is a strong expression of support for moderate forces in both countries.\"\n\nHowever, \"it is regrettable that the Israeli government shows no signs of engaging constructively,\" Barth Eide said. \"The international community must increase its political and economic support for Palestine and continue the work for a two-state solution.\"\n\nLast week, Norway, along with Spain and Ireland, said in a coordinated effort that they were recognizing a Palestinian state.\n\nSPAIN WILL BEGIN RECOGNIZING A PALESTINIAN STATE\n\nMADRID -- Spain moved to formally recognize a Palestinian state with Ireland and Norway to follow suit on Tuesday in a coordinated effort by the three western European nations. Israel slammed the diplomatic move that will have no immediate impact on its grinding war in Gaza but adds to international pressure to soften its devastating response to October's Hamas-led attack.\n\nIsraeli Foreign Minister Israel Katz accused Spain of \"being complicit in inciting genocide against Jews and war crimes\" and told the country that its consulate in Jerusalem will not be allowed to help Palestinians.\n\nPrime Minister Pedro S\u00e1nchez, who announced his country's decision before parliament last week, has spent months touring European and Middle Eastern countries to garner support for recognition and a cease-fire in Gaza.\n\nRelations between the EU and Israel nosedived Monday, the eve of the diplomatic recognition EU members Ireland and Spain, with Madrid insisting that sanctions should be considered against Israel for its continued deadly attacks in southern Gaza's city of Rafah.\n\nIRANIAN PARLIAMENT REELECTS HARD-LINER QALIBAF AS ITS SPEAKER\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates -- Iran's parliament reelected hard-liner Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf on Tuesday as its speaker, reaffirming its hard-right makeup in the wake of a helicopter crash that killed the country's president and foreign minister.\n\nOf 287 lawmakers voting Tuesday, 198 backed Qalibaf to retain the position he first took in 2021. He initially became speaker following a string of failed presidential bids and 12 years as the leader of Iran's capital city. Many, however, know Qalibaf for his support as a Revolutionary Guard general for a violent crackdown on Iranian university students in 1999. He also reportedly ordered live gunfire to be used against Iranian students in 2003 while serving as the country's police chief.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. {"uri": "2024-05-371165849", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "17:26:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T17:26:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T17:13:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/tanks-reach-heart-gaza-rafah-171302415.html", "title": "Tanks reach heart of Gaza's Rafah as Israeli bombardment mounts", "body": "Israeli tanks have pushed into the centre of Rafah for the first time as Israeli forces bombard the Gaza border city where hundreds of thousands of people are sheltering.\n\nIt came as the UK called for \"swift and transparent\" full investigation into an airstrike and subsequent blaze that killed at least 45 people in a tent camp in the city on Sunday. The strike on the Tel al-Sultan neighbourhood, which the Palestinian Red Crescent said is partially located in a designated humanitarian zone, has led to an international outcry. More than half of the dead are said to be women, children and the elderly.\n\nOn Tuesday, Palestinian officials claimed that at least another 21 people had been killed in tank shelling that hit another tent camp in al-Mawasi in western Rafah. The Israeli military denied this. \"Contrary to the reports from the last few hours, the IDF did not strike in the Humanitarian Area in al-Mawasi,\" a statement said.\n\nIn an earlier statement, the Israeli army said that an initial investigation by their own forces into the strike on Sunday found that the blaze near the tent camp was caused by a secondary explosion. Chief military spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said that it was still unclear what set off the deadly blaze, but said that the military fired two 17-kilogram munitions that targeted two senior Hamas militants. He said the munitions would have been too small to ignite a fire on their own and the military is looking into the possibility that weapons were stored in the area. The fire could have ignited fuel, cooking gas canisters or other materials in the densely populated camp where people were sheltering under little more than tarpaulin and cloth.\n\nBritain's foreign secretary, David Cameron, described the the scenes of Sunday's strike as \"deeply depressing\" and urged Israeli military to conduct a \"swift, comprehensive, and transparent\" probe.\n\n\"Deeply distressing scenes following the airstrikes in Rafah this weekend,: Lord Cameron wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter.\n\n\"The IDF's investigation must be swift, comprehensive & transparent. We urgently need a deal to get hostages out & aid in, with a pause in fighting to allow work towards a long-term sustainable ceasefire.\"\n\nA Downing Street spokesman said \" the UK would not support a major military operation in Rafah unless we see a plan to protect the hundreds of thousands of civilians who remain there. He added that Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has made this point to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.\n\nMr Netanyahu has called the deadly strike on Sunday a \"tragic mishap\".\n\nMeanwhile, Israeli tanks pressed ahead with their offensive into Rafah. Tanks and armoured vehicles mounted with machine guns were spotted near Al-Awda mosque, a central Rafah landmark, the witnesses told Reuters.\n\nSince May Israel has mounted a ferocious ground assault into Rafah causing nearly a million people, most of them displaced multiple times to flee.\n\nThey are now seeking refuge in squalid tent camps with dwindling water, food and medical supplies in other war-ravaged strip. In places like Khan Younis, which is further north and heavily destroyed civilians told The Independent they were struggling to find water.\n\nThe United States, the UK and other allies of Israel have warned against a full-fledged offensive in the city, with the Biden administration saying that would cross\" a red line\" and refusing to provide offensive arms for such an undertaking.\n\nOn Friday, the International Court of Justice called on Israel to halt its Rafah offensive. Israel has continued its offensive saying the court's ruling grants it some scope for military action in Rafah. The court also reiterated calls for the immediate and unconditional release of hostages held in Gaza by Hamas.\n\nIsrael launched its most ferocious bombardment of Gaza ever in retaliation for the 7 October attack by Hamas on southern Israel, during which they killed around 1,200 people and took over 250 hostage.\n\nSince then Palestinian officials say Israel's bombing has killed more than 36,000 people the majority women and children. The focus has, in recent months, been Rafah.\n\nPalestinian health ministry officials told The Independent the city was being pounded with ferocious air strikes and tank fire, and that new strikes in the Tel al-Sultan district - the district where Sunday's strike hit - killed at least 16 Palestinians.\n\nThe Israeli military said its forces continued to operate in the Rafah area, without commenting on reported advances into the city centre.\n\nThere are also concerns about the health system. Most of Gaza's hospitals are no longer functioning. Medics at the Kuwait Hospital in Rafah told The Independent it shut down Monday after a strike near its entrance killed two health workers.\n\nPalestinian health ministry officials in Gaza said two medical facilities in Tel al-Sultan are out of service because of intense bombing nearby.\n\nA spokesperson for the World Health Organization said the casualties from Sunday's strike and fire \"absolutely overwhelmed\" field hospitals in the area, which were already running short on supplies to treat severe burns.\n\nMoamen, 27, who is displaced from the very north of Gaza, and was in the camp that was targeted on Sunday said most of the people remained in the area as they had been told it was in the humanitarian zone and they had no money to go anywhere les.e\n\n\" I heard three missiles and a huge, very powerful explosion that shook the place. It appears that the rockets used were incendiary, as fires broke out in the area,\" he told The Independent.\n\n\"It was a terrifying scene. I saw dismembered body parts and charred bodies, very large destruction in the tents of the displaced over a wide area,\" he added.\n\nIn a diplomatic move aimed at reining in the violence, Spain, Ireland and Norway officially recognised a Palestinian state on Tuesday, deepening Israel's international isolation over the war.\n\nThe three countries have said they hope their decision will {"uri": "8150404102", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "19:26:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T19:26:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T19:25:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/civil-defence-says-21-dead-in-new-strike-on-gaza-camp-that-israel-denies/article_0e558e0a-00a4-55f0-94e5-81e001663b87.html", "title": "Civil defence says 21 dead in new strike on Gaza camp that Israel denies", "body": "Palestinians flee the area of Tal al-Sultan in Rafah with their belongings following renewed Israeli strikes in the city in the southern Gaza Strip on May 28, 2024\n\nA civil defence official in Hamas-run Gaza said an Israeli strike on a displacement camp west of Rafah on Tuesday killed at least 21 people, after a similar strike that sparked global outrage.\n\nIsrael denied carrying out the latest reported strike, which occurred hours ahead of a UN Security Council meeting to discuss a Sunday strike which Palestinian officials said killed 45 people.\n\nDespite mounting concerns over the civilian toll of its war on Hamas, Israel has shown no signs of changing course and international efforts aimed at securing a ceasefire remain stalled.\n\nIn the latest bloodshed, Gaza's civil defence agency official Mohammad al-Mughayyir said 21 people were killed in an \"occupation strike targeting the tents of displaced people\" in west Rafah. Hamas said an Israeli strike on the area caused \"dozens of martyrs and wounded\".\n\nIsrael's army rejected the allegations, saying it \"did not strike\" the designated humanitarian area in Al-Mawasi.\n\nIn Rafah, residents and a Palestinian security source said Israeli tanks had now penetrated the heart of the southern city.\n\n\"People are currently inside their homes because anyone who moves is being shot at by Israeli drones,\" one resident, Abdel Khatib, said.\n\n- 'Random bombing' -\n\nAn emergency United Nations Security Council meeting is due to discuss Sunday's deadly strike at 1915 GMT.\n\nAhead of the meeting, Israel's military said the weapons used in that strike \"could not\" have caused the deadly blaze in the camp.\n\n\"Our munition alone could not have ignited a fire of this size,\" said military spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari.\n\nSunday evening's strike, which medics said also wounded hundreds of civilians, drew worldwide condemnation.\n\nThe sight of the charred carnage, blackened corpses and children being rushed to hospitals led UN chief Antonio Guterres to declare that \"there is no safe place in Gaza. This horror must stop.\"\n\nIsrael's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu referred to the strike as a \"tragic accident\" but affirmed the continuation of the campaign to destroy Hamas over the October 7 attack and to bring home all the hostages.\n\nPalestinian militant group Islamic Jihad on Tuesday released a video showing an Israeli hostage alive and held in Gaza, identified by Israeli media as Sasha Trupanov, 28.\n\nAir strikes and shelling battered Gaza overnight Monday-Tuesday -- including the Tal al-Sultan area where the displacement camp went up in flames near a facility of the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, UNRWA.\n\nFaten Jouda, a 30-year-old resident, described the situation as very dangerous.\n\n\"We didn't sleep all night. There was random bombing from all directions, including artillery shelling and air bombardment as well as firing from aircraft.\n\n\"We saw everyone fleeing again,\" she told AFP. \"We too will go now and head to Al-Mawasi because we fear for our lives,\" she said of the nearby coastal area Israel has declared a safe \"humanitarian zone\".\n\n- Palestinian statehood - More from this section Emma Raducanu 'has a different view of things' after skipping French Open to focus on Wimbledon Friday's preholiday travel breaks the record for the most airline travelers screened at US airports COVID-19 wiped out a decade of life expectancy gains, WHO says\n\nUNRWA said one million civilians had fled Rafah since Israel launched its assault on the city in early May despite a chorus of international warnings.\n\nNearly eight months into the deadliest Gaza war, Israel has faced ever louder opposition, as well as cases before two Netherlands-based international courts.\n\nIn a landmark move on Tuesday, Ireland, Norway and Spain formally recognised the State of Palestine, a step so far taken by more than 140 UN members but few Western governments.\n\nSpanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said the recognition was \"not only a matter of historic justice... it is also an essential requirement if we are all to achieve peace\".\n\n\"It is the only way to move towards the solution that we all recognise as the only possible way to achieve a peaceful future: that of a Palestinian state living side by side with the State of Israel in peace and security.\"\n\nIrish Prime Minister Simon Harris said the aim was to keep Middle East peace hopes alive, and urged Israel to \"stop the humanitarian catastrophe\" in Gaza.\n\nIsrael has slammed the recognition as a \"reward\" for the Islamist Hamas movement, and recalled its diplomatic envoys from Madrid, Dublin and Oslo.\n\nForeign Minister Israel Katz went further and attacked Sanchez on X, telling him that \"you are a partner to incitement to genocide of the Jewish people\".\n\nSpanish Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Albares said the three governments would \"issue a coordinated response\" to Israel which would be \"calm but firm\".\n\n- 'Hell on Earth' -\n\nThe Gaza war was sparked by Hamas's October 7 attack on southern Israel, which resulted in the deaths of more than 1,189 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on the latest Israeli official figures.\n\nMilitants also took 252 hostages, 121 of whom remain in Gaza, including 37 the army says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory offensive has killed at least 36,096 people in Gaza, mostly civilians, according to the territory's health ministry.\n\nSunday night's attack that killed dozens in the displaced persons camp was targeting two senior Hamas members, the Israeli military said.\n\nIt said aircraft \"struck a Hamas compound\" and killed Yassin Rabia and Khaled Nagar, senior officials for the group in the occupied West Bank.\n\nThe strike came hours after Hamas fired a barrage of rockets towards Tel Aviv, with most being intercepted.\n\nThe civilian death toll in the Gaza camp prompted a wave of condemnation, with Palestinians and many Arab countries calling it a \"massacre\".\n\nUNRWA chief Philippe Lazzarini said Monday that \"the images from last night are testament to how Rafah has turned into hell on Earth\".\n\nOn the diplomatic front, Egypt has \"intensified efforts to relaunch\" negotiations for a \"truce and a detainee exchange deal\", the state-linked Al-Qahera News reported.\n\nburs-jd/dv/srm", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-371133626", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "16:53:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T16:53:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T16:39:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/the-latest-fighting-escalates-in-rafah-as-israel-pushes-ahead-with-its-offensive/article_0d8ef6b4-0782-5f79-8e19-aeaeee3ae905.html", "title": "The Latest | Fighting escalates in Rafah as Israel pushes ahead with its offensive", "body": "Palestinian residents of the southern Gaza city of Rafah have reported an escalation of fighting Tuesday as Israeli forces pressed their assault on the border town once seen as the territory's last refuge.\n\nIsrael says it is carrying out limited operations in eastern Rafah along the Gaza-Egypt border, as the United States and other allies of Israel have warned against a full-fledged offensive in the city.\n\nIsraeli leaders say their forces must enter Rafah to dismantle Hamas and return hostages taken in the Oct. 7 attack that triggered the war.\n\nFighting in Rafah has caused nearly 1 million Palestinians to flee, most of whom had already been displaced in the war between Israel and Hamas. They now seek refuge in squalid tent camps and other war-ravaged areas, where they lack shelter, food, water and other essentials for survival, the U.N. says.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to the Health Ministry, which doesn't distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nIsrael launched its war in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attack in which militants stormed into southern Israel, killed some 1,200 people -- mostly civilians -- and abducted about 250. Israel says around 100 hostages are still captive in Gaza, along with the bodies of around 30 more.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- Spain, Norway and Ireland formally recognize a Palestinian state as EU rift with Israel widens.\n\n-- Netanyahu says deadly Israeli strike in Rafah over the weekend was the result of a \"tragic mishap.\"\n\n-- As Israel attacks Rafah, Palestinians are living in tents and scrounging for food.\n\n-- An Israeli strike in southern Lebanon kills 2 people near a hospital, officials say.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of the war in Gaza at https://apnews.com/hub/israel-hamas-war.\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nWOMEN AND GIRLS SUFFERING THE MOST IN GAZA, SAYS HEAD OF U.N. AGENCY FOR GENDER EQUALITY\n\nUNITED NATIONS - The head of the United Nations agency promoting gender equality is demanding a halt to the war in Gaza, saying women and girls are suffering the most.\n\nSima Bahous, executive director of U.N. Women, said Tuesday more than 10,000 women have been killed in the seven months of fighting - including scores of women and children \"horrifically killed\" by an Israeli airstrike Monday while sleeping in tents in what was supposed to be a safe zone in Gaza's southern city of Rafah.\n\nBahous told a U.N. Security Council meeting it is \"for all women and girls caught in this conflict that we demand a permanent cease-fire, unhindered humanitarian access, the release of all hostages, the determined pursuit of peace, and a two-state solution.\"\n\n\"This war must stop because women and girls are bearing the brunt of it,\" Bahous told the meeting on the role of women and youth in promoting international peace and security.\n\nISRAELI ARMY SAYS FIRE IN RAFAH AIRSTRIKE WAS CAUSED BY SECONDARY BLAST\n\nJERUSALEM -- The Israeli military says an initial investigation into a strike that sparked a deadly fire in a tent camp in the southern Gaza city of Rafah has found the blaze was caused by a secondary explosion.\n\nRear Adm. Daniel Hagari, the chief military spokesman, said Tuesday that the military fired two 17-kilogram (37-pound) munitions that targeted two senior Hamas militants. He said the munitions would have been too small to ignite a fire on their own and that the military is looking into the possibility that weapons were stored in the area.\n\nThe strike or subsequent fire also could have ignited fuel, cooking gas canisters or other materials in the densely populated tent camp housing displaced people.\n\nPalestinian health officials say at least 45 people, around half of them women and children, were killed in Sunday's strike.\n\nThe strike caused widespread outrage, including from some of Israel's closest allies. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said it was the result of a \"tragic mishap.\"\n\nISRAELI STRIKES ON RAFAH KILL AT LEAST 16 PALESTINIANS, FIRST RESPONDERS SAY\n\nDEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip -- Israeli strikes on Rafah have killed at least 16 Palestinians overnight, first responders said Tuesday, as residents reported an escalation of fighting in the southern Gaza city.\n\nAn Israeli incursion launched earlier this month has caused nearly 1 million to flee from Rafah, most of whom have already been displaced in the war between Israel and Hamas, and who are now seeking refuge in squalid tent camps and war-ravaged areas.\n\nThe latest strikes occurred in the same area where Israel targeted what it said was a Hamas compound on Sunday night. That strike ignited a fire in a camp for displaced Palestinians and killed at least 45 people, according to local health officials, sparking worldwide outrage.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said there was a \"tragic mishap\" on Sunday and the military said it was investigating.\n\nThe latest strikes killed a total of 16 people in the Tel al-Sultan neighborhood in northwest Rafah, according to the Palestinian Civil Defense and the Palestinian Red Crescent.\n\nNORWAY FORMALLY RECOGNIZES A PALESTINIAN STATE\n\nCOPENHAGEN, Denmark -- Norway on Tuesday formally recognized a Palestinian state with the Scandinavian foreign minister calling it \"a milestone in the relationship between Norway and Palestine.\"\n\nForeign Minister Espen Barth Eide said \"the recognition is a strong expression of support for moderate forces in both countries.\"\n\nHowever, \"it is regrettable that the Israeli government shows no signs of engaging constructively,\" Barth Eide said. \"The international community must increase its political and economic support for Palestine and continue the work for a two-state solution.\"\n\nLast week, Norway, along with Spain and Ireland, said in a coordinated effort that they were recognizing a Palestinian state.\n\nSPAIN WILL BEGIN RECOGNIZING A PALESTINIAN STATE\n\nMADRID -- Spain moved to formally recognize a Palestinian state with Ireland and Norway to follow suit on Tuesday in a coordinated effort by the three western European nations. Israel slammed the diplomatic move that will have no immediate impact on its grinding war in Gaza but adds to international pressure to soften its devastating response to October's Hamas-led attack.\n\nIsraeli Foreign Minister Israel Katz accused Spain of \"being complicit in inciting genocide against Jews and war crimes\" and told the country that its consulate in Jerusalem will not be allowed to help Palestinians.\n\nPrime Minister Pedro S\u00e1nchez, who announced his country's decision before parliament last week, has spent months touring European and Middle Eastern countries to garner support for recognition and a cease-fire in Gaza.\n\nRelations between the EU and Israel nosedived Monday, the eve of the diplomatic recognition EU members Ireland and Spain, with Madrid insisting that sanctions should be considered against Israel for its continued deadly attacks in southern Gaza's city of Rafah.\n\nIRANIAN PARLIAMENT REELECTS HARD-LINER QALIBAF AS ITS SPEAKER\n\nDUBAI, United Arab Emirates -- Iran's parliament reelected hard-liner Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf on Tuesday as its speaker, reaffirming its hard-right makeup in the wake of a helicopter crash that killed the country's president and foreign minister.\n\nOf 287 lawmakers voting Tuesday, 198 backed Qalibaf to retain the position he first took in 2021. He initially became speaker following a string of failed presidential bids and 12 years as the leader of Iran's capital city. Many, however, know Qalibaf for his support as a Revolutionary Guard general for a violent crackdown on Iranian university students in 1999. He also reportedly ordered live gunfire to be used against Iranian students in 2003 while serving as the country's police chief.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Responsibility For Attack On Refugee Tent Encampment In Rafah", "body": "At least 21 displaced civilians killed in Israeli shelling of refugee tents in al Mawasi area west of Rafah.\n\nThe Israeli army on Tuesday denied responsibility for the killing of at least 21 displaced Palestinians west of Rafah.\n\nAt least 21 people were killed on Tuesday in Israeli shelling of a refugee tent encampment in al-Mawasi area west of Rafah, in the third such attack on areas designated by Tel Aviv as a \"safe zone\" in the last 48 hours, the Rafah Emergency Committee said.\n\nThe targeted tent encampment is located around 100 meters away from a US field hospital west of Rafah, according to Palestinian sources.\n\n\"Contrary to the reports from the last few hours, the IDF (army) did not strike in the Humanitarian Area in al-Mawasi,\" military spokesman Daniel Hagari claimed in a statement.\n\nDespite the international outcry, the Israeli army renewed its attacks on the Tel al-Sultan area in Rafah early Tuesday, resulting in the deaths of seven Palestinians and the injuries of others.\n\nThe attack came after at least 45 civilians were killed and dozens injured in an Israeli strike on a tent encampment in Tel al-Sudan on Sunday.\n\nAccording to Gaza's government media office, at least 72 displaced civilians were killed in Israeli attacks on refugee tents in Rafah in the last 48 hours.\n\nIsrael expanded its ground offensive in Rafah on Tuesday, with its tanks reaching the center of the city.\n\nIsrael's current expansion of its incursion into the city makes the Israeli army close to fully control the border area between Gaza and Egypt, known as the Philadelphi Corridor, a demilitarized buffer zone running along the Gaza-Egypt border.\n\nThe Israeli army has so far seized control of almost two-thirds of the corridor area as it advances under heavy bombardment and shelling.\n\nIsrael has continued its brutal offensive on the Gaza Strip since Oct. 7, 2023 following a Hamas attack despite a UN Security Council resolution demanding an immediate cease-fire in the enclave.\n\nNearly 36,100 Palestinians have since been killed in Gaza, the vast majority being women and children, and over 81,000 others injured, according to local health authorities.\n\nNearly eight months into the Israeli war, vast swathes of Gaza lay in ruins amid a crippling blockade of food, clean water and medicine.\n\nIsrael stands accused of \"genocide\" at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), which in its latest ruling has ordered Tel Aviv to immediately halt its operation in Rafah, where over a million Palestinians had sought refuge from the war before it was invaded on May 6.\n\n*Writing by Mohammad Sio -", "source": {"uri": "en.haberler.com", "dataType": "news", "title": army on Tuesday denied responsibility for the killing of at least 21 displaced Palestinians west of Rafah.\n\nAt least 21 people were killed on Tuesday in Israeli shelling of a refugee tent encampment in al-Mawasi area west of Rafah, in the third such attack on areas designated by Tel Aviv as a \"safe zone\" in the last 48 hours, the Rafah Emergency Committee said.\n\nThe targeted tent encampment is located around 100 meters away from a US field hospital west of Rafah, according to Palestinian sources.\n\n\"Contrary to the reports from the last few hours, the IDF (army) did not strike in the Humanitarian Area in al-Mawasi,\" military spokesman Daniel Hagari claimed in a statement.\n\nDespite the international outcry, the Israeli army renewed its attacks on the Tel al-Sultan area in Rafah early Tuesday, resulting in the deaths of seven Palestinians and the injuries of others.\n\nThe attack came after at least 45 civilians were killed and dozens injured in an Israeli strike on a tent encampment in Tel al-Sudan on Sunday.\n\nAccording to Gaza's government media office, at least 72 displaced civilians were killed in Israeli attacks on refugee tents in Rafah in the last 48 hours.\n\nIsrael expanded its ground offensive in Rafah on Tuesday, with its tanks reaching the center of the city.\n\nIsrael's current expansion of its incursion into the city makes the Israeli army close to fully control the border area between Gaza and Egypt, known as the Philadelphi Corridor, a demilitarized buffer zone running along the Gaza-Egypt border.\n\nThe Israeli army has so far seized control of almost two-thirds of the corridor area as it advances under heavy bombardment and shelling.\n\nIsrael has continued its brutal offensive on the Gaza Strip since Oct. 7, 2023 following a Hamas attack despite a UN Security Council resolution demanding an immediate cease-fire in the enclave.\n\nNearly 36,100 Palestinians have since been killed in Gaza, the vast majority being women and children, and over 81,000 others injured, according to local health authorities.\n\nNearly eight months into the Israeli war, vast swathes of Gaza lay in ruins amid a crippling blockade of food, clean water and medicine.\n\nIsrael stands accused of \"genocide\" at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), which in its latest ruling has ordered Tel Aviv to immediately halt its operation in Rafah, where over a million Palestinians had sought refuge from the war before it was invaded on May 6.", "source": {"uri": "aa.com.tr", "dataType": "news", "title": "Anadolu Ajans\u0131"}, "authors": [], In a statement issued hours before the meeting, Israel's military said the weapons used in Sunday's strike \"could not\" have caused the deadly blaze in the Rafah camp.\n\n\"Our munition alone could not have ignited a fire of this size,\" said military spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari.\n\nWorldwide condemnation\n\nSunday evening's strike, which medics said also wounded hundreds of civilians, drew worldwide condemnation. The sight of the charred carnage, blackened corpses and children being rushed to hospitals led UN chief Antonio Guterres to declare that \"there is no safe place in Gaza. This horror must stop.\"\n\nIsrael's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called the strike a \"tragic accident\" but also vowed to continue the campaign to destroy Hamas over the October 7 attack and bring home all the hostages.\n\nMore air strikes and shelling rained down overnight on besieged Gaza - including the Tal al-Sultan area where the displacement camp went up in flames near a facility of the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, UNRWA. UNRWA said 1 million civilians had fled Rafah since Israel launched its assault on the city in early May despite a chorus of international warnings.\n\n\"This happened with nowhere safe to go & amidst bombardments, lack of food & water, piles of waste & unsuitable living conditions,\" it posted on X.\n\nSunday night's attack that killed dozens in the displaced persons camp was targeting two senior Hamas members, the Israeli military said. {"uri": "8150438974", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "19:59:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T19:59:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T19:57:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.nigeriasun.com/news/274387939/us-urges-israel-to-fully-investigate-deadly-strike-in-rafah-camp", "title": "US urges Israel to fully investigate deadly strike in Rafah camp", "body": "The United States expressed \"deep concern\" Tuesday over an apparent Israeli airstrike on Sunday that killed at least 45 Palestinians sheltering in a refugee camp in Rafah, and wounded 200 others.\n\n\"Those images were heartbreaking,\" U.S. State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller told reporters.\n\nHe said while Israel has a right to go after Hamas, Israel has an obligation to do everything possible to minimize civilian harm while it carries out its operations.\n\n'We will continue to emphasize to Israel their obligation to comply fully with international humanitarian law, minimize the impact of their operations on civilians and maximize the flow of humanitarian assistance to those in need,' Miller said, adding Israel's military had promised a swift, comprehensive and transparent investigation.\n\n\"We will be watching those results closely,' he said.\n\nIsrael's military said it is looking into the possibility that weapons stored in the area hit by the Israeli strike may have sparked a deadly fire at the refugee camp Sunday. A military spokesman said Tuesday the munitions used in the Israeli strike were too small to set off a big blaze.\n\nA Palestinian child, wounded in an Israeli strike on an area designated for displaced people, is assisted at a hospital, amid the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas, in Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip, May 26, 2024.\n\nThe Gaza health ministry said the attack ignited tent fires in an area sheltering displaced people. Israel said it killed two senior Hamas militants in the attack.\n\nThe U.N. Security Council was meeting Tuesday afternoon in a closed session requested by member Algeria to discuss the attack.\n\nU.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said in a statement Tuesday that the \"relentless violence\" must stop and reiterated his call for a humanitarian cease-fire and the unconditional and immediate release of all hostages.\n\nGaza medical personnel and residents reported new Israeli airstrikes Tuesday in the area of al-Mawasi on the enclave's coast, where thousands of people have fled to what Israel has said is a designated 'safe zone.\"\n\nThe Gaza health ministry said at least 20 civilians were killed. The Israel Defense Forces denied striking the area.\n\nDisplaced Palestinians inspect their tents destroyed by Israel's bombardment, adjunct to an UNRWA facility west of Rafah city, Gaza Strip, May 28, 2024.\n\nThe U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees, UNRWA, said Tuesday that more than 940,000 people have fled Rafah in the past three weeks amid Israel's offensive. Another 100,000 have been displaced by fighting in northern Gaza.\n\nU.N. humanitarian chief Martin Griffiths issued a statement late Monday calling the Rafah attack \"utterly unacceptable.\" He criticized Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's explanation that what happened was a \"tragic mistake.\"\n\n\"Whether the attack was a war crime or a 'tragic mistake,' for the people of Gaza, there is no debate,\" Griffiths said. \"What happened last night was the latest - and possibly most cruel - abomination. To call it 'a mistake' is a message that means nothing for those killed, those grieving, and those trying to save lives.\"\n\nGriffiths said the U.N. \"warned that a military operation in Rafah would lead to a slaughter\" and added that there are no safe areas or humanitarian zones in Gaza.\n\n'Despite our best effort, not to harm those not involved, unfortunately a tragic mistake happened last night. We are investigating the case,' Netanyahu told the Israeli parliament.\n\nNetanyahu has repeatedly said Israel needs to carry out an offensive in Rafah in order to achieve its goal of ensuring Hamas cannot operate in Gaza and threaten Israel in the future.\n\nVolker T\u00fcrk, the U.N. high commissioner for human rights, decried the Rafah attack, saying in a statement Monday, 'The images from the camp are horrific and point to no apparent change in the methods and means of warfare used by Israel that have already led to so many civilian deaths.'\n\nFILE - U.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Turk is shown on Aug. 9, 2023.\n\nEven as he noted the Israeli military's announced investigation, T\u00fcrk said it was 'shockingly clear' that the decision to strike an area 'densely packed with civilians' would result in the 'entirely predictable outcome' of the death of more Palestinian civilians.\n\nT\u00fcrk called on Israel to abide by last week's International Court of Justice order to totally halt its offensive in Rafah. He also urged Palestinian armed groups to stop firing rockets indiscriminately into Israel 'in clear violation of international humanitarian law' and release all the remaining 100 or so hostages Hamas is holding in Gaza.\n\nEuropean Council President Charles Michel also called the strikes \"horrendous\" and urged Israel to stop its offensive in Rafah.\n\n\"Horrendous to see innocent Palestinian civilians killed in the recent attack. There is no safe zone for the internally displaced in Rafah,\" Michel said on the X social media platform.\n\nQatar's foreign ministry said Monday that the attack could complicate efforts to mediate stalled cease-fire talks and the return of the hostages held in Gaza.\n\nThe Israel-Hamas war was triggered by the October 7 Hamas attack on Israel that killed 1,200 people, according to Israeli officials, and led to the capture of about 250 hostages. Israel's subsequent counteroffensive has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, a death toll that includes both civilians and combatants, according to the Gaza health ministry.\n\nU.N. correspondent Margaret Besheer contributed to this report. An Israeli military spokesperson said: \"As of this time, we are not aware of this incident.\"\n\nIn central Rafah, tanks and armoured vehicles mounted with machineguns were spotted near Al-Awda mosque, witnesses told Reuters. The Israeli military said its forces continued to operate in the Rafah area, without commenting on reported advances into the city centre.\n\nInternational unease over Israel's three-week-old Rafah offensive has turned to outrage after an attack on Sunday set off a blaze in a tent camp in a western district of the city, killing at least 45 people.\n\nAt Algeria's request, the UN Security Council was scheduled to hold an urgent closed-door session later yesterday to discuss the situation in Rafah.\n\nGlobal leaders voiced horror at the fire in a designated \"humanitarian zone\" of Rafah where families uprooted by fighting elsewhere had sought shelter, and urged the implementation of a World Court order last week for a halt to Israel's assault.\n\nIn a diplomatic move purportedly aimed at reining in the violence, Spain, Ireland and Norway officially recognised a Palestinian state yesterday.\n\nThe three countries have said they hope their decision will accelerate efforts towards securing a ceasefire in Israel's offensive in Gaza, now in its eighth month, that has reduced much of the densely populated territory to rubble.\n\nThe health ministry in Gaza said yesterday that at least 36,096 Palestinians have been killed in the territory during the offensive. The toll includes at least 46 deaths over the past 24 hours, a ministry statement said.\n\nResidents said Rafah's Tel Al-Sultan neighbourhood, the scene of Sunday's night-time strike in which tents and shelters were set ablaze as families settled down to sleep, was still being bombarded.\n\nAround one million people - many repeatedly displaced by shifting waves of the offensive - have fled the Israeli offensive in Rafah since early May, the UN agency for Palestinian refugees (UNRWA) reported yesterday.\n\nA video obtained by Reuters showed families on the move again, carrying their {"uri": "2024-05-371224061", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "18:38:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T18:38:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T18:25:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/us-deeply-saddened-israeli-strike-182539465.html", "title": "US 'deeply saddened' by Israeli strike on Rafah camp that killed dozens, but will wait for investigation", "body": "The State Department said it was \"deeply saddened\" by the Israeli airstrike on a displaced persons camp in Rafah that killed dozens of Palestinians on Sunday and prompted global outrage -- but US officials are waiting for an investigation before taking any action.\n\nGraphic videos and photos shared online from the aftermath of the strike showed a person appearing to be burned alive, bodies of women and children who had been burned, and a man holding up the body of a baby who had been seemingly decapitated.\n\nAt least 50 Palestinians were killed and dozens more injured in the attack that targeted an area filled with tents, many of which caught on fire, according to the Gaza health authorities.\n\nWitnesses said a further 37 people were killed on Tuesday by Israeli shelling and airstrikes, most of them while they were sheltering in tents in the same area where the deadly strikes on Sunday killed dozens. They also said Israel tanks had moved into the centre of Rafah.\n\nState Department spokesman Matthew Miller said on Tuesday that the US has reached out to Israel to demand an investigation and raise concerns about the initial strike.\n\n\"The [Israeli army] is continuing to investigate this matter and has promised that its investigation will be swift, comprehensive and transparent. We will be watching those results closely,\" he said.\n\nThe attack prompted immediate global condemnation from world leaders, aid groups and concerned citizens, while the White House has remained largely silent over the past few days.\n\nFrench president Emmanuel Macron said he was \"outraged by the Israeli strikes that have killed many displaced persons in Rafah.\"\n\n\"These operations must stop. There are no safe areas in Rafah for Palestinian civilians,\" he added, calling for an immediate ceasefire.\n\nUnited Nations Secretary-General Ant\u00f2nio Guterres was similarly forceful in his response. \"I condemn Israel's actions which killed scores of innocent civilians who were only seeking shelter from this deadly conflict,\" he said on X. \"There is no safe place in Gaza. This horror must stop.\"\n\nThe strike came just two days after the International Court of Justice ordered Israel to \"immediately halt its military offensive\" in Rafah in a landmark emergency ruling that invoked the Genocide Convention.\n\nThe attack is likely to increase pressure on Mr Biden to reevaluate his support for Israel's war in Gaza, after vowing to withhold offensive weapons from the longtime US ally if it launched a major operation in Rafah.\n\nMr Biden has repeatedly expressed his strong opposition to a major offensive in Rafah, which had become the last refuge for more than a million Palestinians who had fled from the war raging in other parts of Gaza. It is also where most aid agencies are operating.\n\nIn a March interview with MSNBC, when asked whether an Israeli invasion of Rafah would be a red line for him, he replied: \"It is a red line but I'm never going to leave Israel. The defense of Israel is still critical.\"\n\nHis officials have repeatedly said the US would not support a \"major military operation\" in Gaza's southern city without a \"credible ... executable\" plan to protect civilians.\n\nMr Miller said Israel's operation in Gaza was not of the \"scale\" of previous operations that had prompted US concern, but he said the US was \"watching closely.\"\n\nVice president Kamala Harris did not comment when questioned if the attack breached Mr Biden's red line, but said: \"The word tragic doesn't even begin to describe it.\"\n\nThe Israeli army quickly claimed response for the attack on Sunday, claiming its air force had struck a Hamas compound with \"precise ammunition and on the basis of precise intelligence,\" killing two Hamas officials in the process. But the next day, Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu called the incident a \"tragic mishap\" in an address to Israel's parliament and promised an investigation.\n\nThe Israeli army said Tuesday that it was investigating the possibility that a secondary explosion caused by weapons stored near where the strike occurred may have set tents ablaze.", "source": {"uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", {"uri": "8150153196", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "16:06:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T16:06:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T16:05:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.palestinechronicle.com/one-million-palestinians-have-fled-rafah-amid-israels-invasion-unrwa/", "title": "'One Million Palestinians Have Fled Rafah' amid Israel's Invasion - UNRWA", "body": "Nearly one million Palestinians have fled the southern Gazan town of Rafah, amid the Israeli military's ongoing incursion into the city, the UN Agency for Palestine Refugees (UNRWA) has said.\n\n\"In the past 3 weeks around 1 million people have fled Rafah,\" UNRWA said on X on Tuesday. \"This happened with nowhere safe to go & amidst bombardments, lack of food & water, piles of waste & unsuitable living conditions.\"\n\nThe UN agency added, \"Day after day, providing assistance & protection becomes nearly impossible.\"\n\nIt reiterated its call for an immediate ceasefire.\n\n'Heinous Crime' - Hamas Condemns Israeli Bombing of Displacement Camp in Rafah\n\nRafah housed more than 1.5 million displaced Palestinians before the ground invasion began on May 6. Many had fled their homes in areas across the besieged enclave which was attacked by Israeli forces.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Israeli army began expanding its incursion into Rafah amid heavy shelling and bombing, forcing thousands to flee western Rafah towards Khan Younis and areas in the central Gaza Strip.\n\nAt least 45 Palestinians were killed in an Israeli airstrike on a camp for the displaced in Rafah on Sunday, causing a fire that spread rapidly through the tents. Footage showed charred bodies, as well as a man holding a beheaded baby as screams were heard all around him.\n\nUNRWA's Commissioner-General, Philippe Lazzarini, said on Monday that images from the attack \"are testament to how Rafah has turned into hell on earth.\"\n\nLazzarini said UNRWA is doing \"everything possible\" not to interrupt the delivery of humanitarian assistance.\n\n\"But with every day passing, providing assistance & protection becomes nearly impossible,\" he stressed.\n\nThe UNRWA Chief said he echoed the dismay expressed by UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres at the \"lack of implementation\" of the recent court order by the International Court of Justice regarding Rafah, emphasizing that \"The decisions of the ICJ are binding.\"\n\nHe warned that the military operation in Rafah \"must immediately end & the flow of humanitarian assistance into Gaza must improve without further delay.\"\n\nThe ICJ on Friday ordered Israel to halt its ground invasion of Rafah, withdraw its forces and ensure unimpeded humanitarian aid into the enclave.\n\nIsrael has however intensified its attacks on the town.\n\nAt least 20 people were killed and many others wounded on Tuesday in a new massacre carried out by the Israeli occupation army, which bombed a camp for displaced people in the Al-Mawasi area of Rafah.\n\nhttps://twitter.com/PalestineChron/status/1795486141988413768\n\nCurrently on trial before the International Court of Justice for genocide against Palestinians, Israel has been waging a devastating war on Gaza since October 7.\n\nAccording to Gaza's Ministry of Health, 36,096 Palestinians have been killed, and 81,136 wounded in Israel's ongoing genocide in Gaza starting on October 7.\n\nMoreover, at least 11,000 people are unaccounted for, presumed dead under the rubble of their homes throughout the Strip.\n\nPalestinian and international organizations say that the majority of those killed and wounded are women and children.\n\nInternational Court of Justice Orders Immediate Halt of Israel's Operation in Rafah - BREAKING\n\nThe Israeli war has resulted in an acute famine, mostly in northern Gaza, resulting in the death of many Palestinians, mostly children.\n\nThe Israeli aggression has also resulted in the forceful displacement of nearly two million people from all over the Gaza Strip, with the vast majority of the displaced forced into the densely crowded southern city of Rafah near the border with Egypt - in what has become Palestine's largest mass exodus since the 1948 Nakba.\n\nIsrael says that 1,200 soldiers and civilians were killed during the Al-Aqsa Flood Operation on October 7.
